# images Module - Chapter Specification

<!-- BEGIN VERBATIM SPEC: DO NOT EDIT BELOW. This block is auto-generated by scripts/vendor_css_spec.sh -->

<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="2" id="image-values"><span class="secno">2. </span><span class="content">2D Image Values: the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image②">&lt;image></a> type</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-values"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image③">&lt;image></a> value type denotes a 2D image. It can be a <a href="#url-notation">url reference</a>, <a href="#image-notation">image notation</a>,
	or <a href="#gradients">gradient notation</a>.
	Its syntax is:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-image">&lt;image></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value">&lt;url></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①">&lt;<c- nf>image</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set">&lt;<c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade">&lt;<c- nf>cross-fade</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one③">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①">&lt;<c- nf>element</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one④">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-gradient" id="ref-for-typedef-gradient">&lt;gradient></a></pre>
   <p>An <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image④">&lt;image></a> can be used in many CSS properties,
	including the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-image" id="ref-for-propdef-background-image">background-image</a>, <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#propdef-list-style-image" id="ref-for-propdef-list-style-image">list-style-image</a>, <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-ui-4/#propdef-cursor" id="ref-for-propdef-cursor">cursor</a> properties <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css2" title="Cascading Style Sheets Level 2 Revision 1 (CSS 2.1) Specification">[CSS2]</a> (where it replaces the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value①">&lt;url></a> component in the property’s value).</p>
   <p>In some cases an image is invalid,
	such as a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value②">&lt;url></a> pointing to a resource that is not a valid image format
	or that has failed to load.
	An <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="invalid image|valid image" id="invalid-image">invalid image</dfn> is rendered
	as a solid-color <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#valdef-color-transparent" id="ref-for-valdef-color-transparent">transparent</a> image with no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions">natural dimensions</a>.
	However, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image">invalid images</a> can trigger error-handling clauses
	in some contexts.
	For example, an <span id="ref-for-invalid-image①">invalid image</span> in <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#propdef-list-style-image" id="ref-for-propdef-list-style-image①">list-style-image</a> it is treated as <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#valdef-list-style-type-none" id="ref-for-valdef-list-style-type-none">none</a>,
	allowing the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#propdef-list-style-type" id="ref-for-propdef-list-style-type">list-style-type</a> to render in its place. <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css2" title="Cascading Style Sheets Level 2 Revision 1 (CSS 2.1) Specification">[CSS2]</a></p>
   <p>While an image is loading,
	is a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="loading-image">loading image</dfn>. <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#loading-image" id="ref-for-loading-image">Loading images</a> are <em>not</em> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image②">invalid images</a>,
	but have similar behavior:
	they are rendered as a solid-color <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#valdef-color-transparent" id="ref-for-valdef-color-transparent①">transparent</a> image with no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions①">natural dimensions</a>,
	and may trigger fallback rendering in contexts that offer it,
	but must not trigger loading of fallback resources.
	Alternately, if a <span id="ref-for-loading-image①">loading image</span> happens to be replacing
	an already-loaded image
	(for example due to changes in the document or style sheet)
	and the UA is tracking this information,
	it may continue to render the already-loaded image
	in place of the <span id="ref-for-loading-image②">loading image</span>.</p>
   <p>Partially-loaded images (whose <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions②">natural dimensions</a> are known, but whose image data is not fully loaded)
	may be either treated as <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#loading-image" id="ref-for-loading-image③">loading images</a> or as loaded images rendered with partial data.
	For example, a UA may render an interlaced GIF in place
	as soon as its first pass of pixel data has loaded
	or even as soon as the image header (which contains sizing data) has parsed
	and refresh the rendering as more data loads;
	or it may wait until the entire image has loaded before using it.</p>
   <p>A <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="computed-image"><a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade-5/#computed-value" id="ref-for-computed-value">computed</a> <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image⑤">&lt;image></a></dfn> value
	is the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade-5/#specified-value" id="ref-for-specified-value">specified value</a> with any <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value③">&lt;url></a>s, <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color">&lt;color></a>s, and <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value">&lt;length></a>s computed.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.1" id="image-file-formats"><span class="secno">2.1. </span><span class="content">Image File Formats</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-file-formats"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>At minimum, the UA must support the following image file formats
	when referenced from an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image⑥">&lt;image></a> value,
	for all the properties in which using <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-image⑦">&lt;image></span> is valid:</p>
   <ul>
    <li>PNG, as specified in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-png" title="Portable Network Graphics (PNG) Specification (Third Edition)">[PNG]</a> 
    <li>SVG, as specified in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg11" title="Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1 (Second Edition)">[SVG11]</a>,
		using the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/svg-integration/#secure-static-mode">secure static mode</a> (See <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg-integration" title="SVG Integration">[SVG-INTEGRATION]</a>) 
    <li>If the UA supports animated <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image⑧">&lt;image></a>s,
		SVG, as specified in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg11" title="Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1 (Second Edition)">[SVG11]</a>,
		using the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/svg-integration/#secure-animated-mode">secure animated mode</a> (See <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg-integration" title="SVG Integration">[SVG-INTEGRATION]</a>) 
   </ul>
   <p>The UA may support other file formats as well.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.2" id="url-notation"><span class="secno">2.2. </span><span class="content">Image References: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#funcdef-url" id="ref-for-funcdef-url">url()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#url-notation"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> No change from <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-images-3" title="CSS Images Module Level 3">[css-images-3]</a>.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.3" id="fetching-images"><span class="secno">2.3. </span><span class="content">Fetching External Images</span><a class="self-link" href="#fetching-images"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>To <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="fetch-an-external-image-for-a-stylesheet">fetch an external image for a stylesheet</dfn>,
	given a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value④">&lt;url></a> <var>url</var> and a <a data-link-type="dfn">CSS style declaration</a> <var>declaration</var>, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#fetch-a-style-resource" id="ref-for-fetch-a-style-resource">fetch a style resource</a> given <var>url</var>,
	with ruleOrDeclaration being <var>declaration</var>,
	destination "image",
	CORS mode "no-cors",
	and processResponse being the following steps
	given <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://fetch.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-response" id="ref-for-concept-response">response</a> <var>res</var> and null, failure or
	a byte stream <var>byteStream</var>:
		If <var>byteStream</var> is a byte stream, load the image from the byte stream.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.4" id="image-set-notation"><span class="secno">2.4. </span><span class="content">Resolution/Type Negotiation: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①">image-set()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-set-notation"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>Delivering the most appropriate image resolution for a user’s device can be a difficult task.
	Ideally, images should be in the same resolution as the device they’re being viewed in,
	which can vary between users.
	However, other factors can factor into the decision of which image to send;
	for example, if the user is on a slow mobile connection,
	they may prefer to receive lower-res images
	rather than waiting for a large proper-res image to load.
	The <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-image-set">image-set()</dfn> function allows an author to ignore most of these issues,
	simply providing multiple resolutions of an image
	and letting the UA decide which is most appropriate in a given situation.</p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-86c01534"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-86c01534"></a> This solution assumes that resolution is a proxy for filesize,
	and therefore doesn’t appropriately handle multi-resolution sets of vector images,
	or mixing vector images with raster ones (e.g. for icons).
	For example, use a vector for high-res,
	pixel-optimized bitmap for low-res,
	and same vector again for low-bandwidth (because it’s much smaller, even though it’s higher resolution).</p>
   <p>The syntax for <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set②">image-set()</a> is:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set③">&lt;<c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> = <c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>(</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option">&lt;image-set-option></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma">#</a> <c- p>)</c->
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-image-set-option">&lt;image-set-option></dfn> = <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image⑨">&lt;image></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one⑤">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value">&lt;string></a> <c- p>]</c->
                     <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value">&lt;resolution></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any">||</a> <c- nf>type</c-><c- p>(</c-><a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value①">&lt;string></a><c- p>)</c-> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt">?</a>
</pre>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-372ac642"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-372ac642"></a> We should add "w" and "h" dimensions as a possibility
	to match the functionality of HTML’s <a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/embedded-content.html#the-picture-element" id="ref-for-the-picture-element">picture</a>.</p>
   <p>Each <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value②">&lt;string></a> inside <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set④">image-set()</a> represents a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value⑤">&lt;url></a>.</p>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set⑤">image-set()</a> function can not be nested inside of itself,
	either directly
	or indirectly
	(as an argument to another <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⓪">&lt;image></a> type).</p>
   <p>Each <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option①">&lt;image-set-option></a> defines a possible image for the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set⑥">image-set()</a> function to represent,
	composed of three parts:</p>
   <ul>
    <li data-md>
     <p>An image reference (required).
This can be a URL,
or a CSS generated image,
such as a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient">linear-gradient()</a>.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>A <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value①">&lt;resolution></a> (optional).
This is used to help the UA decide which <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option②">&lt;image-set-option></a> to choose.
If the image reference is for a raster image,
it also specifies the image’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#--natural-resolution" id="ref-for---natural-resolution">natural resolution</a>,
overriding any other source of data that might supply a <span id="ref-for---natural-resolution①">natural resolution</span>.</p>
     <p>If not specified,
it behaves as <span class="css">1x</span> for the purpose of selecting which <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option③">&lt;image-set-option></a> to use.
It also <em>defaults</em> the image’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#--natural-resolution" id="ref-for---natural-resolution②">natural resolution</a> to <span class="css">1x</span>,
but if some other source of data supplies a <span id="ref-for---natural-resolution③">natural resolution</span>,
that resolution must be honored instead.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>A <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="image-set()" data-dfn-type="function" data-export data-lt="type()" id="funcdef-image-set-type">type( <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value③">&lt;string></a> )</dfn> function (optional),
specifying the image’s MIME type in the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value④">&lt;string></a>.</p>
     <p>If the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value⑤">&lt;string></a>,
when parsed as a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://mimesniff.spec.whatwg.org/#valid-mime-type" id="ref-for-valid-mime-type">valid MIME type string</a>,
is either not valid,
or is valid but doesn’t specify a supported image format,
the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option④">&lt;image-set-option></a> does not define a valid option.
(This has no effect on the validity of the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set⑦">image-set()</a> function.)</p>
     <p>It does not have any effect on the image itself;
an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option⑤">&lt;image-set-option></a> like <code class="highlight"><c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"picture.png"</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- m>1</c-><c- k>x</c-> <c- nf>type</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"image/jpeg"</c-><c- p>)</c-></code> is valid,
and if chosen will display the linked PNG image,
even though it was declared to be a JPEG.</p>
     <p>If not specified,
it has no effect on the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option⑥">&lt;image-set-option></a>.</p>
   </ul>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-all-options-invalid.html" title="css/css-images/image-set/image-set-all-options-invalid.html">image-set-all-options-invalid.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-all-options-invalid.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-all-options-invalid.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-calc-x-rendering-2.html" title="css/css-images/image-set/image-set-calc-x-rendering-2.html">image-set-calc-x-rendering-2.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-calc-x-rendering-2.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/image-set/image-set-calc-x-rendering-2.html"><small>(source)</small></a>

    </ul>
   </details>
   <p>An <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set⑧">image-set()</a> function contains a list of one or more <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option⑦">&lt;image-set-option></a>s,
	and must select only one of them
	to determine what image it will represent:</p>
   <ol>
    <li data-md>
     <p>First, remove any <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option⑧">&lt;image-set-option></a>s from the list
that specify an unknown or unsupported MIME type in their <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set-type" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set-type">type()</a> value.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Second, remove any <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option⑨">&lt;image-set-option></a>s from the list
that have the same <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value②">&lt;resolution></a> as a previous option in the list.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>If there are no <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option①⓪">&lt;image-set-option></a> left at this point,
the function represents an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image③">invalid image</a>.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Finally, among the remaining <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option①①">&lt;image-set-option></a>s,
make a UA-specific choice of which to load,
based on whatever criteria deemed relevant
(such as the resolution of the display,
	connection speed,
	etc).</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set⑨">image-set()</a> function then represents the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①①">&lt;image></a> of the chosen <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option①②">&lt;image-set-option></a>.</p>
   </ol>
   <p>UAs <strong>may</strong> change which <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-set-option" id="ref-for-typedef-image-set-option①③">&lt;image-set-option></a> they wish to use for a given <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①⓪">image-set()</a> over the lifetime of the page,
	if the criteria used to determine which option to choose change significantly enough to make it worthwhile in the UA’s estimation.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-set">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-set"></a> This example shows how to use <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①①">image-set()</a> to provide an image in three versions:
		a "normal" version,
		a "high-res" version,
		and an extra-high resolution version for use in high-quality printing
		(as printers can have <em>extremely</em> high resolution): 
<pre class="highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- s>"foo.png"</c-> <c- m>1</c-><c- k>x</c-><c- p>,</c->
                             <c- s>"foo-2x.png"</c-> <c- m>2</c-><c- k>x</c-><c- p>,</c->
                             <c- s>"foo-print.png"</c-> <c- m>600</c-><c- k>dpi</c-> <c- p>);</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-set-type">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-set-type"></a> This example shows use of the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set-type" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set-type①">type()</a> function
		to serve multiple versions of the same image
		in both new, higher-quality formats,
		and older, more widely-supported formats: 
<pre class="highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- s>"foo.avif"</c-> <c- nf>type</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"image/avif"</c-><c- p>),</c->
                             <c- s>"foo.jpg"</c-> <c- nf>type</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"image/jpeg"</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- p>);</c->
</pre>
    <p>Note that the AVIF image is given first;
		since both images have the same resolution
		(defaulting to <span class="css">1x</span> since it’s unspecified),
		the JPEG image,
		coming second,
		is automatically dropped in UAs that support AVIF images.</p>
    <p>In older UAs, however,
		the AVIF image is ignored
		(because the UA knows it doesn’t support <code class="highlight"><c- s>"image/avif"</c-></code> files),
		and so the JPEG is chosen instead.</p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="eximage-set-multi-resolution">
    <a class="self-link" href="#eximage-set-multi-resolution"></a> Raster images can be mixed with vector images,
		or even CSS generated images. 
    <p>For example, in this code snippet
		a high-resolution image with subtle details is used on screens that can do it justice,
		while an ordinary CSS <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient①">linear-gradient()</a> is used instead for low-resolution situations:</p>
<pre class="highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image-set</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->cornflowerblue<c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>)</c-> <c- m>1</c-><c- k>x</c-><c- p>,</c->
                             <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"detailed-gradient.png"</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- m>3</c-><c- k>x</c-> <c- p>);</c->
</pre>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.5" id="image-notation"><span class="secno">2.5. </span><span class="content">Image Fallbacks and Annotations: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image②">image()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-notation"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image③">image()</a> function allows an author to:</p>
   <ul>
    <li data-md>
     <p>use <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/media-frags/">media fragments</a> to clip out a portion of an image</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>use a solid color as an image</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>fallback to a solid-color image, when the image at the specified url can’t be downloaded or decoded</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>automatically respect the image orientation specified in the image’s metadata</p>
   </ul>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image④">image()</a> notation is defined as:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-image"><c- nf>image</c-><c- p>()</c-></dfn> = <c- nf>image</c-><c- p>(</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-tags" id="ref-for-typedef-image-tags">&lt;image-tags></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①">?</a> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-src" id="ref-for-typedef-image-src">&lt;image-src></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt②">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma"><c- p>,</c-></a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①">&lt;color></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt③">?</a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-req" id="ref-for-mult-req">!</a> <c- p>)</c->
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-image-tags">&lt;image-tags></dfn> = <c- p>[</c-> ltr <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one⑥">|</a> rtl <c- p>]</c->
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-image-src">&lt;image-src></dfn> = <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value⑥">&lt;url></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one⑦">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value⑥">&lt;string></a> <c- p>]</c->
</pre>
   <p>A <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#string-value" id="ref-for-string-value⑦">&lt;string></a> used in <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image⑤">image()</a> represents a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#url-value" id="ref-for-url-value⑦">&lt;url></a>.
	As usual for URLs in CSS,
	relative URLs are resolved to an absolute URL
	(as described in Values &amp; Units <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-values-3" title="CSS Values and Units Module Level 3">[CSS-VALUES-3]</a>)
	when a specified <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image⑥">image()</span> value is computed.</p>
   <p>If the image has an orientation specified in its metadata,
	such as EXIF,
	the UA must rotate or flip the image to correctly orient it
	as the metadata specifies.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.5.1" id="image-fallbacks"><span class="secno">2.5.1. </span><span class="content">Image Fallbacks</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-fallbacks"></a></h4>
   <p>If both a URL and a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color②">&lt;color></a> are specified in <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image⑦">image()</a>,
	then whenever the URL represents an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image④">invalid image</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#loading-image" id="ref-for-loading-image④">loading image</a>,
	the <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image⑧">image()</span> function renders as if the URL were not specified at all;
	it generates a solid-color image as specified in <a href="#color-images">§ 2.5.3 Solid-color Images</a>.</p>
   <p>If just a URL is specified (no <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color③">&lt;color></a>)
	and it represents an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image⑤">invalid image</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#loading-image" id="ref-for-loading-image⑤">loading image</a>,
	the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image⑨">image()</a> function represents the same.</p>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations.html" title="css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations.html">css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations002.html" title="css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations002.html">css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations002.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations002.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations002.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations003.html" title="css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations003.html">css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations003.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations003.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations003.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations004.html" title="css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations004.html">css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations004.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations004.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations004.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations005.html" title="css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations005.html">css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations005.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations005.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/css-image-fallbacks-and-annotations005.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <div class="example" id="ex-fallback">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-fallback"></a> The fallback color can be used to ensure that text is still readable
		even when the image fails to load.
		For example, the following legacy code works fine if the image is rectangular and has no transparency: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight">body      <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> black<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
p.special <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"dark.png"</c-><c- p>)</c-> black<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>When the image doesn’t load,
		the background color is still there to ensure that the white text is readable.
		However, if the image has some transparency,
		the black will be visible behind it,
		which is probably not desired.
		The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①⓪">image()</a> function addresses this:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight">body      <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> black<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
p.special <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> white<c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"dark.png"</c-><c- p>,</c-> black<c- p>);</c-> <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>Now, the black won’t show at all if the image loads,
		but if for whatever reason the image fails,
		it’ll pop in and prevent the white text from being set against a white background.</p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.5.2" id="image-fragments"><span class="secno">2.5.2. </span><span class="content">Image Fragments</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-fragments"></a></h4>
   <p>When a URL specified in <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①①">image()</a> represents a portion of a resource
	(e.g. by the use of <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/media-frags/#naming-space">media fragment identifiers</a>)
	that portion is clipped out of its context and used as a standalone image.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-fragment">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-fragment"></a> For example, given the following image and CSS: 
    <p><a href="images/sprites.svg"> <img alt="[9 circles, with 0 to 8 eighths filled in]" height="20" src="images/sprites.svg" width="180"> </a></p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>'sprites.svg#xywh=40,0,20,20'</c-><c- p>)</c-></pre>
    <p>...the background of the element will be the portion of the image that starts at (40px,0px) and is 20px wide and tall,
		which is just the circle with a quarter filled in.</p>
   </div>
   <p>So that authors can take advantage of CSS’s forwards-compatible parsing rules to provide a fallback for image slices,
	implementations that support the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①②">image()</a> notation <em>must</em> support the <code class="highlight">xywh=#<c- p>,</c->#<c- p>,</c->#<c- p>,</c->#</code> form of media fragment identifiers
	for images specified via <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①③">image()</span>. <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-media-frags" title="Media Fragments URI 1.0 (basic)">[MEDIA-FRAGS]</a></p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-fragment-fallback">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-fragment-fallback"></a> Note that image fragments can also be used with the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#funcdef-url" id="ref-for-funcdef-url①">url()</a> notation.
		However, a legacy UA that doesn’t understand the media fragments notation
		will ignore the fragment and simply display the entirety of the image. 
    <p>Since the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①④">image()</a> notation requires UAs to support media fragments,
		authors can take advantage of CSS’s forward-compatible parsing rules
		to provide a fallback when using an image fragment URL:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>'swirl.png'</c-><c- p>);</c-> <c- c>/* old UAs */</c->
background-image: <c- nf>image</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>'sprites.png#xywh=10,30,60,20'</c-><c- p>);</c-> <c- c>/* new UAs */</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <p>If a URL uses a fragment identifier syntax that the implementation does not understand,
	or does not consider valid for that type of image,
	the URL must be treated as representing an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image⑥">invalid image</a>.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> This error-handling is limited to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①⑤">image()</a>,
	and not in the definition of URL,
	for legacy compat reasons.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.5.3" id="color-images"><span class="secno">2.5.3. </span><span class="content">Solid-color Images</span><a class="self-link" href="#color-images"></a></h4>
   <p>If the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image" id="ref-for-funcdef-image①⑥">image()</a> function is specified with only a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color④">&lt;color></a> argument (no URL),
	it represents a solid-color image of the specified color with no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions③">natural dimensions</a>.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-solid-color">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-solid-color"></a> For example,
		one can use this as a simple way to "tint" a background image,
		by overlaying a partially-transparent color over the top of the other image: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>image</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- nf>rgba</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>255</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>.5</c-><c- p>)),</c-> <c- nf>url</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- s>"bg-image.png"</c-><c- p>);</c-></pre>
    <p><a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-color" id="ref-for-propdef-background-color">background-color</a> does not work for this,
		as the solid color it generates always lies <em>beneath</em> all the background images.</p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.5.4" id="bidi-images"><span class="secno">2.5.4. </span><span class="content">Bidi-sensitive Images</span><a class="self-link" href="#bidi-images"></a></h4>
   <p>Before listing any <code class="highlight">&lt;image-src>s</code>,
	the author may specify a directionality for the image,
	similar to adding a <code class="highlight">dir</code> attribute to an element in HTML.
	If a directional image is used on or in an element with opposite <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/visuren.html#propdef-direction">direction</a>,
	the image must be flipped in the inline direction
	(as if it was transformed by, e.g., <code class="highlight"><c- nf>scaleX</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>-1</c-><c- p>)</c-></code>, if the inline direction is the X axis).</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Absent this declaration,
	images default to no directionality at all,
	and thus don’t care about the directionality of the surrounding element.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-directionality">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-directionality"></a> A list may use an arrow for a bullet that points into the content.
		If the list can contain both LTR and RTL text,
		though, the bullet may be on the left or the right,
		and an image designed to point into the text on one side will point out of the text on the other side.
		This can be fixed with code like: 
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>ul</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"list-style-image: image(ltr 'arrow.png');"</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-> <c- e>dir</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'ltr'</c-><c- p>></c->My bullet is on the left!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-> <c- e>dir</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'rtl'</c-><c- p>></c->MY BULLET IS ON THE RIGHT!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>ul</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
    <p>This should render something like:</p>
<pre class="lang-html highlight">⇒ My bullet is on the left!
  !THGIR EHT NO SI TELLUB YM ⇐
</pre>
    <p>In LTR list items, the image will be used as-is.
		In the RTL list items, however,
		it will be flipped in the inline direction,
		so it still points into the content.</p>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="2.6" id="cross-fade-function"><span class="secno">2.6. </span><span class="content">Combining images: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①">cross-fade()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#cross-fade-function"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>When transitioning between images,
	CSS requires a way to explicitly refer to the intermediate image
	that is a combination of the start and end images.
	This is accomplished with the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade②">cross-fade()</a> function,
	which indicates the two images to be combined
	and how far along in the transition the combination is.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Authors can also use the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade③">cross-fade()</a> function for many simple image manipulations,
	such as tinting an image with a solid color
	or highlighting a particular area of the page by combining an image with a radial gradient.</p>
   <p>The syntax for <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade④">cross-fade()</a> is defined as:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled caniuse-paneled" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-cross-fade"><c- nf>cross-fade</c-><c- p>()</c-></dfn> = <c- nf>cross-fade</c-><c- p>(</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-cf-image" id="ref-for-typedef-cf-image">&lt;cf-image></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma①">#</a> <c- p>)</c->
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-cf-image">&lt;cf-image></dfn> = <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①②">&lt;image></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one⑧">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color⑤">&lt;color></a> <c- p>]</c-> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-all" id="ref-for-comb-all">&amp;&amp;</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value">&lt;percentage <c- p>[</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>100</c-><c- p>]</c->></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt④">?</a> 
</pre>
   <p>The function represents an image generated by
	combining one or more images.</p>
   <p>The <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value①">&lt;percentage></a> represents how much of each image is retained
	when it is blended with the other images.
	The <span class="production" id="ref-for-percentage-value②">&lt;percentage></span> must be between <span class="css">0%</span> and <span class="css">100%</span> inclusive;
	any other value is invalid.</p>
   <p>If any percentages are omitted,
	all the specified percentages are summed together
	and subtracted from <span class="css">100%</span>,
	the result is floored at <span class="css">0%</span>,
	then divided equally between all images with omitted percentages
	at computed-value time.</p>
   <div class="note" role="note">
     While this is not reflected in the computed value,
		when all the arguments’ percentages sum to greater than <span class="css">100%</span>,
		the sizing/painting details effectively rescale them so that they sum to exactly <span class="css">100%</span>. 
    <p>On the other hand,
		when the sum is less than <span class="css">100%</span>,
		the sizing/painting details effectively act like there’s an additional <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#valdef-color-transparent" id="ref-for-valdef-color-transparent②">transparent</a> argument,
		with its percentage set to the remaining value
		necessary to make the sum equal <span class="css">100%</span>.</p>
   </div>
   <p>If a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color⑥">&lt;color></a> is provided,
	it represents a solid-color image
	with “automatic” dimensions
	(it doesn’t participate in the sizing of the result image at all;
	see details in the sizing details below).</p>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-basic.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-basic.html">cross-fade-basic.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-basic.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-basic.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-computed-value.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-computed-value.html">cross-fade-computed-value.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-computed-value.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-computed-value.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-crash.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-crash.html">cross-fade-legacy-crash.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-crash.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-crash.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-2-crash.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-2-crash.html">cross-fade-legacy-2-crash.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-2-crash.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-legacy-2-crash.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-natural-size.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-natural-size.html">cross-fade-natural-size.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-natural-size.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-natural-size.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-premultiplied-alpha.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-premultiplied-alpha.html">cross-fade-premultiplied-alpha.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-premultiplied-alpha.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-premultiplied-alpha.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/cross-fade-target-alpha.html" title="css/css-images/cross-fade-target-alpha.html">cross-fade-target-alpha.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/cross-fade-target-alpha.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/cross-fade-target-alpha.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.6.1" id="cross-fade-sizing"><span class="secno">2.6.1. </span><span class="content"><a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade⑤">cross-fade()</a> Sizing</span><a class="self-link" href="#cross-fade-sizing"></a></h4>
   <p>The dimensions of the image represented by a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade⑥">cross-fade()</a> are a weighted average of dimensions of the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①③">&lt;image></a> arguments to the function;
	the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color⑦">&lt;color></a> arguments have no effect.
	They are calculated as follows:</p>
   <div class="algorithm" data-algorithm="natural dimensions of a cross-fade()">
     To determine the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="natural-dimensions-of-a-cross-fade"><a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions④">natural dimensions</a> of a cross-fade()</dfn>: 
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#normalize-mix-percentages" id="ref-for-normalize-mix-percentages">Normalize mix percentages</a> from the function’s arguments,
and let <var>args</var> and <var>leftover</var> be the result.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>If <var>leftover</var> is 100%,
return no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions⑤">natural dimensions</a>.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Let <var>images</var> be an empty list.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>For each <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-cf-image" id="ref-for-typedef-cf-image①">&lt;cf-image></a> <var>argument</var> of the function’s arguments:</p>
      <ol>
       <li data-md>
        <p>If <var>argument</var> is not an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①④">&lt;image></a>,
or is an <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⑤">&lt;image></span> with no natural dimensions, <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#iteration-continue" id="ref-for-iteration-continue">continue</a>.</p>
       <li data-md>
        <p>Let <var>item</var> be a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#tuple" id="ref-for-tuple">tuple</a> consisting of a width, a height, and a percentage.</p>
       <li data-md>
        <p>Run the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#object-size-negotiation" id="ref-for-object-size-negotiation">object size negotiation</a> algorithm for the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⑥">&lt;image></a>,
as appropriate for the context in which the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade⑦">cross-fade()</a> appears,
and set <var>item</var>’s width and height
to the width and height of the resulting <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size">concrete object size</a>.</p>
       <li data-md>
        <p>Set <var>item</var>’s percentage to the <var>argument</var>’s percentage.</p>
      </ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p>If <var>images</var> is empty,
return no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions⑥">natural dimensions</a>.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Return a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-width" id="ref-for-natural-width">natural width</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-height" id="ref-for-natural-height">natural height</a> that are weighted averages of the width and height
of each item in <var>images</var>,
according to their corresponding percentages.</p>
      <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The percentages might sum to a value less than 100%,
so a naive weighted-averaging process might need to normalize them first.</p>
    </ol>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.6.2" id="cross-fade-painting"><span class="secno">2.6.2. </span><span class="content"><a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade⑧">cross-fade()</a> Painting</span><a class="self-link" href="#cross-fade-painting"></a></h4>
   <p>The image represented by a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade⑨">cross-fade()</a> is a weighted average of the input arguments to the function,
	calculated as follows:</p>
   <div class="algorithm" data-algorithm="appearance of a cross-fade()">
     To determine the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="appearance-of-a-cross-fade">appearance of a cross-fade()</dfn>: 
    <ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://drafts.csswg.org/css-values-5/#normalize-mix-percentages" id="ref-for-normalize-mix-percentages①">Normalize mix percentages</a> from the function’s arguments,
and let <var>args</var> and <var>leftover</var> be the result.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Let <var>images</var> be an empty list.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Let <var>size</var> be a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#tuple" id="ref-for-tuple①">tuple</a> of width and height,
initialized to the result of finding the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①">concrete object size</a> of the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①⓪">cross-fade()</a> function
(using the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#natural-dimensions-of-a-cross-fade" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions-of-a-cross-fade">natural dimensions of a cross-fade()</a>).</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>For each <var>argument</var> of the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①①">cross-fade()</a> function:</p>
      <ol>
       <li data-md>
        <p>Let <var>item</var> be a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#tuple" id="ref-for-tuple②">tuple</a> consisting of an image and a percentage.</p>
       <li data-md>
        <p>If <var>argument</var> has an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⑦">&lt;image></a>,
rescale it to <var>size</var>’s width and height
and set <var>item</var>’s image to the result.
Otherwise, <var>argument</var> has a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color⑧">&lt;color></a>;
set <var>item</var>’s image to a solid-color image of the <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-color⑨">&lt;color></span>,
with <var>size</var>’s dimensions.</p>
       <li data-md>
        <p>Set <var>item</var>’s percentage to the <var>argument</var>’s percentage.</p>
      </ol>
     <li data-md>
      <p>If <var>leftover</var> is greater than <span class="css">0%</span>,
append a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#tuple" id="ref-for-tuple③">tuple</a> to <var>images</var> consisting of a solid-color transparent-black image
with <var>size</var>’s dimensions,
and a percentage equal to <var>leftover</var>.</p>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Let <var>final image</var> be an image
with <var>size</var>’s dimensions,
and every pixel being the weighted linear average of the corresponding pixels of <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://infra.spec.whatwg.org/#list-iterate" id="ref-for-list-iterate">each</a> <var>item</var>’s image in <var>images</var>,
weighted according to the <var>item</var>’s percentage.
(Average both the color channels and the alpha channel of the pixels.)
For the purpose of this calculation,
each pixel’s color must be in pre-multiplied sRGB.</p>
      <details class="note">
       <summary>Details on the above operation</summary>
       <p>This is applying an N-way Porter-Duff <code class="highlight">dissolve</code> operation to the source images.
	Wikipedia defines <code class="highlight">dissolve</code> as a stochastic operation,
	with the result pixels independently randomly chosen from the source images’ corresponding pixels
	according to their source images’ weights,
	but as pixels shrink to infinitely small,
	this converges to doing color-averaging in pre-multiplied color space.</p>
       <p>In particular, this means that `cross-fade(white 50%, transparent 50%)`
	will produce a partially-transparent solid white image.
	(Rather than a partially-transparent gray,
	which is what you’d get if you averaged the opaque white and transparent black pixels
	in non-premultiplied space.)</p>
       <p>As converting to pre-multiplied does entail some loss of precision,
	and graphics libraries may or may not support this operation natively,
	as per usual any method can be used so long as it achieves the specified effect.</p>
       <p>For example, one can instead rebalance the percentages
	according to the alphas of each pixel,
	then do the color-channel averages in non-premultiplied space.
	E.g., to render <span class="css">cross-fade(rgb(255 0 0 / 1) 40%, rgb(0 255 0 / .5) 20%, rgb(0 0 255 / 0) 40%)</span>,
	rebalancing the percentages according to the 1 / .5 / 0 alphas
	would produce 40% / 10% / 0%
	(which renormalizes to 80% / 20% / 0%),
	at which point you can average the raw color channel values
	and end up with an <span class="css">rgb(204 51 0 / .5)</span> image.
	(Note that the alpha channel is still averaged using the original percentages,
	not the rebalanced ones.)</p>
      </details>
     <li data-md>
      <p>Return <var>final image</var>.</p>
    </ol>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.6.3" id="cross-fade-complex"><span class="secno">2.6.3. </span><span class="content">Simplifying Complex <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①②">cross-fade()</a></span><a class="self-link" href="#cross-fade-complex"></a></h4>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-efd818cb"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-efd818cb"></a> Per WG resolution,
	define a notion of "equality" for images,
	and combine "same" images at computed-value time,
	summing their percentages.</p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-84499f31"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-84499f31"></a> Per WG resolution,
	simplify directly-nested <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①③">cross-fade()</a> at computed-value time
	by just distributing the percentage and flattening; <span class="css">cross-fade(A 10%, cross-fade(B 30%, C 70%) 90%)</span> becomes <span class="css">cross-fade(A 10%, B 27%, C 63%)</span>.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled caniuse-paneled" data-level="2.7" id="element-notation"><span class="secno">2.7. </span><span class="content">Using Elements as Images: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element②">element()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#element-notation"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element③">element()</a> function allows an author to use an element in the document as an image.
	As the referenced element changes appearance,
	the image changes as well.
	This can be used, for example,
	to create live previews of the next/previous slide in a slideshow,
	or to reference a canvas element for a fancy generated gradient or even an animated background.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element④">element()</a> function only reproduces the <em>appearance</em> of the referenced element,
	not the actual content and its structure.
	Authors should only use this for decorative purposes,
	and must not use <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-element⑤">element()</span> to reproduce an element with significant content across the page.
	Instead, just insert multiple copies of the element into the document.</p>
   <p>The syntax for <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element⑥">element()</a> is:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-element"><c- nf>element</c-><c- p>()</c-></dfn> = <c- nf>element</c-><c- p>(</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors-4/#typedef-id-selector" id="ref-for-typedef-id-selector">&lt;id-selector></a> <c- p>)</c-></pre>
   <p>where <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors-4/#typedef-id-selector" id="ref-for-typedef-id-selector①">&lt;id-selector></a> is an ID selector <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-select" title="Selectors Level 3">[SELECT]</a>.</p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-734aa3f2"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-734aa3f2"></a> Do we need to be able to refer to elements in external documents
		(such as SVG paint servers)?
		Or is it enough to just use url() for this? </p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-2c656975"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-2c656975"></a> This name conflicts with a somewhat similar function in GCPM.
		This needs to be resolved somehow. </p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-e85fd299"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-e85fd299"></a> Want the ability to do "reflections" of an element,
		either as a background-image on the element or in a pseudo-element.
		This needs to be specially-handled to avoid triggering the cycle-detection. </p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-1b39a877"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-1b39a877"></a> When we have overflow:paged,
		how can we address a single page in the view? </p>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element⑦">element()</a> function references the element matched by its argument.
	The ID is first looked up in the <a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-css-elementsources" id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources">elementSources</a> map,
	as described in that section.
	If it’s not found,
	it’s then matched against the document.
	If multiple elements are matched,
	the function references the first such element.</p>
   <p>The image represented by the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element⑧">element()</a> function can vary based on whether the element is visible in the document:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt> an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#element-not-rendered" id="ref-for-element-not-rendered">element that is rendered</a>,
			is not a descendant of a replaced element,
			and generates a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visuren.html#x43" id="ref-for-x43">stacking context</a> 
    <dd>
      The function represents an image with its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-size" id="ref-for-natural-size">natural size</a> equal to the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="decorated-bounding-box">decorated bounding box</dfn> of the referenced element: 
     <ul>
      <li> for an element rendered using a CSS rendering model,
					the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#decorated-bounding-box" id="ref-for-decorated-bounding-box">decorated bounding box</a> is the smallest axis-aligned rectangle
					that contains the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/2011/CR-css3-background-20110215/#border-image-area">border image areas</a> of all the fragments of the principal box 
      <li> for an element rendered using the SVG rendering model, <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVGTiny12/intro.html#TermDecoratedBoundingBox">the decorated bounding box is defined by SVG</a> 
     </ul>
     <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Because images clip anything outside their bounds by default,
			this means that decorations that extend outside the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#decorated-bounding-box" id="ref-for-decorated-bounding-box①">decorated bounding box</a>,
			like box shadows,
			may be clipped.</p>
     <p>The image is constructed by rendering the referenced element and its descendants
			(at the same size that they would be in the document)
			over an infinite <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#valdef-color-transparent" id="ref-for-valdef-color-transparent③">transparent</a> canvas,
			positioned so that the edges of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#decorated-bounding-box" id="ref-for-decorated-bounding-box②">decorated bounding box</a> are flush with the edges of the image.</p>
     <p class="issue" id="issue-ed057ccb"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-ed057ccb"></a> Requiring some degree of stacking context on the element appears to be required for an efficient implementation.
				Do we need a full stacking context, or just a pseudo-stacking context?
				Should it need to be a stacking context normally,
				or can we just render it as a stacking context when rendering it to element()? </p>
     <p>If the referenced element has a transform applied to it or an ancestor,
			the transform must be ignored when rendering the element as an image. <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css3-transforms" title="CSS Transforms Module Level 1">[CSS3-TRANSFORMS]</a></p>
     <p>If the referenced element is broken across pages,
			the element is displayed as if the page content areas were joined flush in the pagination direction,
			with pages' edges corresponding to the initial containing block’s start edge aligned. <span class="note">Elements broken across lines or columns are just rendered with their <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#decorated-bounding-box" id="ref-for-decorated-bounding-box③">decorated bounding box</a>.</span></p>
     <p>Implementations may either re-use existing bitmap data generated for the referenced element
			or regenerate the display of the element to maximize quality at the image’s size
			(for example, if the implementation detects that the referenced element is an SVG fragment);
			in the latter case, the layout of the referenced element in the image must not be changed by the regeneration process.
			That is, the image must look identical to the referenced element,
			modulo rasterization quality.</p>
     <div class="example" id="ex-element-reuse">
      <a class="self-link" href="#ex-element-reuse"></a> 
      <p>As a somewhat silly example, a <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/grouping-content.html#the-p-element" id="ref-for-the-p-element">p</a></code> element can be reused as a background elsewhere in the document:</p>
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>#</c-><c- nn>src</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>white</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>lime</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>width</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- mi>300</c-><c- b>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>height</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- mi>40</c-><c- b>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>position</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>relative</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>#</c-><c- nn>dst</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>color</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>black</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>element</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- mh>#src</c-><c- p>);</c-> <c- k>padding</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- mi>20</c-><c- b>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>margin</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- mi>20</c-><c- b>px</c-> <c- mi>0</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>p</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'src'</c-><c- p>></c->I’m an ordinary element!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>p</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>p</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'dst'</c-><c- p>></c->I’m using the previous element as my background!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>p</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
      <p><img alt height="133" src="images/element-function.png" width="554"></p>
     </div>
    <dt>an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#element-not-rendered" id="ref-for-element-not-rendered①">element that is not rendered</a>, but which provides a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source">paint source</a> 
    <dd>
      The function represents an image with the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions⑦">natural dimensions</a> and appearance of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source①">paint source</a>.
			The host language defines the size and appearance of paint sources. 
     <div class="example" id="ex-element-not-rendered-ref">
      <a class="self-link" href="#ex-element-not-rendered-ref"></a> For example, the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element⑨">element()</a> function can reference an SVG <code class="highlight">&lt;pattern></code> element in an HTML document: 
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- cp>&lt;!DOCTYPE html></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>svg</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>defs</c-><c- p>></c->
    <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>pattern</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'pattern1'</c-><c- p>></c->
      <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>path</c-> <c- e>d</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'...'</c-><c- p>></c->
    <c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>pattern</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>defs</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>svg</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>p</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"background: element(#pattern1)"</c-><c- p>></c->
  I’m using the pattern as a background!
  If the pattern is changed or animated,
  my background will be updated too!
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>p</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
      <p>HTML also defines that a handful of elements,
				such as <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/canvas.html#canvas" id="ref-for-canvas">canvas</a></code>, <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/embedded-content.html#the-img-element" id="ref-for-the-img-element">img</a></code>, and <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/media.html#video" id="ref-for-video">video</a></code>,
				provide a paint source.
				This means that CSS can, for example,
				reference a canvas that’s being drawn into,
				but not displayed in the page:</p>
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- cp>&lt;!DOCTYPE html></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- a>var</c-> canvas <c- o>=</c-> document<c- p>.</c->querySelector<c- p>(</c-><c- t>'#animated-bullet'</c-><c- p>);</c->
  canvas<c- p>.</c->width <c- o>=</c-> <c- mf>20</c-><c- p>;</c-> canvas<c- p>.</c->height <c- o>=</c-> <c- mf>20</c-><c- p>;</c->
  drawAnimation<c- p>(</c->canvas<c- p>);</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>canvas</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'animated-bullet'</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'display:none'</c-><c- p>>&lt;/</c-><c- f>canvas</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>ul</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"list-style-image: element(#animated-bullet);"</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->I’m using the canvas as a bullet!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->So am I!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->As the canvas is changed over time with Javascript,
      we’ll all update our bullet image with it!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>ul</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
     </div>
    <dt>anything else 
    <dd>
     <p>The function represents an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image⑦">invalid image</a>.</p>
     <div class="example" id="ex-invalid-image">
      <a class="self-link" href="#ex-invalid-image"></a> 
      <p>For example, all of the following <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⓪">element()</a> uses will result in a transparent background:</p>
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- cp>&lt;!DOCTYPE html></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>p</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'one'</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"display:none; position: relative;"</c-><c- p>></c->one<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>p</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>iframe</c-> <c- e>src</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"http://example.com"</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>p</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'two'</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"position: relative;"</c-><c- p>></c->I’m fallback content!<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>p</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>iframe</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>ul</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"background: element(#one);"</c-><c- p>></c->
    A display:none element isn’t rendered, and a P element
    doesn’t provide a paint source.
  <c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"background: element(#two);"</c-><c- p>></c->
    The descendants of a replaced element like an IFRAME
    can’t be used in element() either.
  <c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
  <c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>li</c-> <c- e>style</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>"background: element(#three);"</c-><c- p>></c->
    There’s no element with an id of "three", so this also
    gets rendered as a transparent image.
  <c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>li</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>ul</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
     </div>
   </dl>
   <p>An element is <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="element-not-rendered" id="element-not-rendered">not rendered</dfn> if it does not have an associated box.
	This can happen, for example,
	if the element or an ancestor is <span class="css">display:none</span>.
	Host languages may define additional ways in which an element can be considered not rendered;
	for example, in SVG,
	any descendant of a <code class="highlight">&lt;defs></code> element is considered to be not rendered.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-element-preview">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-element-preview"></a> 
    <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①①">element()</a> function can be put to many uses.
		For example, it can be used to show a preview of the previous or next slide in a slideshow:</p>
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- cp>&lt;!DOCTYPE html></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- a>function</c-> navigateSlides<c- p>()</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- a>var</c-> currentSlide <c- o>=</c-> <c- p>...;</c->
