  document<c- p>.</c->querySelector<c- p>(</c-><c- t>'#prev-slide'</c-><c- p>).</c->id <c- o>=</c-> <c- t>''</c-><c- p>;</c->
  document<c- p>.</c->querySelector<c- p>(</c-><c- t>'#next-slide'</c-><c- p>).</c->id <c- o>=</c-> <c- t>''</c-><c- p>;</c->
  currentSlide<c- p>.</c->previousElementSibling<c- p>.</c->id <c- o>=</c-> <c- t>'prev-slide'</c-><c- p>;</c->
  currentSlide<c- p>.</c->nextElementSibling<c- p>.</c->id <c- o>=</c-> <c- t>'next-slide'</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- p>}</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>.</c-><c- nc>slide</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- c>/* Need to be a stacking context to be element()-able. */</c->
  <c- k>position</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>relative</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- p>}</c->
<c- p>#</c-><c- nn>prev-preview</c-><c- o>,</c-> <c- p>#</c-><c- nn>next-preview</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- k>position</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- kc>fixed</c-><c- p>;</c->
  ...
<c- p>}</c->
<c- p>#</c-><c- nn>prev-preview</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>element</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- mh>#prev</c-><c- g>-slide</c-><c- p>);</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>#</c-><c- nn>next-preview</c-> <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>element</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- mh>#next</c-><c- g>-slide</c-><c- p>);</c-> <c- p>}</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>a</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'prev-preview'</c-><c- p>></c->Previous Slide<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>a</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>a</c-> <c- e>id</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'next-preview'</c-><c- p>></c->Next Slide<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>a</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>section</c-> <c- e>class</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'slide'</c-><c- p>></c->...<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>section</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>section</c-> <c- e>class</c-><c- o>=</c-><c- s>'slide current-slide'</c-><c- p>></c->...<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>section</c-><c- p>></c->
...
</pre>
    <p>In this example, the <code class="highlight">navigateSlides</code> function updates the ids of the next and previous slides,
		which are then displayed in small floating boxes alongside the slides.
		Since you can’t interact with the slides through the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①②">element()</a> function (it’s just an image),
		you could even use <code class="highlight">click</code> handlers on the preview boxes to help navigate through the page.</p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.7.1" id="paint-sources"><span class="secno">2.7.1. </span><span class="content"> Paint Sources</span><a class="self-link" href="#paint-sources"></a></h4>
   <p>Host languages may define that some elements provide a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="paint-source">paint source</dfn>.
	Paint sources have an intrinsic appearance and can obtain a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size②">concrete object size</a> without having to do layout or rendering,
	and so may be used as images even when they’re <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#element-not-rendered" id="ref-for-element-not-rendered②">not rendered</a>.</p>
   <p>In HTML, the <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/embedded-content.html#the-img-element" id="ref-for-the-img-element①">img</a></code>, <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/media.html#video" id="ref-for-video①">video</a></code>, and <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/canvas.html#canvas" id="ref-for-canvas①">canvas</a></code> elements provide paint sources.</p>
   <p>In SVG, any element that provides a <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/pservers.html">paint server</a> provides a paint source. <span class="note">Note: In SVG1.1,
		the <code class="highlight">&lt;linearGradient></code>, <code class="highlight">&lt;radialGradient></code>,
		and <code class="highlight">&lt;pattern></code> elements
		provide paint sources.</span> They are drawn as described in the spec,
	with the coordinate systems defined as follows:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt>objectBoundingBox 
    <dd> The coordinate system has its origin at the top left corner of the rectangle defined by the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size③">concrete object size</a> that it’s being drawn into,
			and the same width and height as the <span id="ref-for-concrete-object-size④">concrete object size</span>.
			A single <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/coords.html#Units">user coordinate</a> is the width and height of the <span id="ref-for-concrete-object-size⑤">concrete object size</span>. 
    <dt>userSpaceOnUse 
    <dd> The coordinate system has its origin at the top left corner of the rectangle defined by the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size⑥">concrete object size</a> that it’s being drawn into,
			and the same width and height as the <span id="ref-for-concrete-object-size⑦">concrete object size</span>. <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/coords.html#Units">User coordinates</a> are sized equivalently to the CSS <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#px" id="ref-for-px">px</a> unit. 
   </dl>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> It is expected that a future version of this module will define ways to refer to paint sources in external documents,
	or ones that are created solely by script and never inserted into a document at all.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.7.2" id="elementsources"><span class="secno">2.7.2. </span><span class="content"> Using Out-Of-Document Sources: the <code class="highlight">ElementSources</code> interface</span><a class="self-link" href="#elementsources"></a></h4>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①③">element()</a> function normally selects elements within a document,
	but elements that provide a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source②">paint source</a> don’t necessarily need to be in-document.
	For example, an HTML <code><a data-link-type="element" href="https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/canvas.html#canvas" id="ref-for-canvas②">canvas</a></code> element can be created, maintained, and drawn into entirely in script,
	with no need for it to be inserted into the document directly.</p>
   <p>All that’s needed is a way to refer to the element,
	as an ID selector cannot select elements outside of the document.
	The <a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-css-elementsources" id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources①">elementSources</a> Map object provides this.</p>
<pre class="idl highlight def"><c- b>partial</c-> <c- b>namespace</c-> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="namespace" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom-1/#namespacedef-css" id="ref-for-namespacedef-css"><c- g>CSS</c-></a> {
  [<a class="idl-code" data-link-type="extended-attribute" href="https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#SameObject" id="ref-for-SameObject"><c- g>SameObject</c-></a>] <c- b>readonly</c-> <c- b>attribute</c-> <a class="idl-code" data-link-type="interface" href="https://webidl.spec.whatwg.org/#idl-any" id="ref-for-idl-any"><c- b>any</c-></a> <dfn class="dfn-paneled idl-code" data-dfn-for="CSS" data-dfn-type="attribute" data-export data-readonly data-type="any" id="dom-css-elementsources"><code class="highlight"><c- g>elementSources</c-></code></dfn>;
};
</pre>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/idlharness.html" title="css/css-images/idlharness.html">idlharness.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/idlharness.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/idlharness.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <p>Any entries in the <a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-css-elementsources" id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources②">elementSources</a> map with a string key
	and a value that is an object providing a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source③">paint source</a> are made available to the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①④">element()</a> function.</p>
   <p>Whenever <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⑤">element()</a> uses an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/selectors-4/#typedef-id-selector" id="ref-for-typedef-id-selector②">&lt;id-selector></a>,
	the ID’s value (without the leading <code class="highlight">#</code> character)
	is first looked up in the <a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-css-elementsources" id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources③">elementSources</a> map:</p>
   <ul>
    <li> If it’s found,
			and the object associated with it provides a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source④">paint source</a>,
			the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⑥">element()</a> function represents that paint source. 
    <li> If it’s found,
			but the object associated with it <em>doesn’t</em> provide a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-source" id="ref-for-paint-source⑤">paint source</a>,
			the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⑦">element()</a> function represent an <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image⑧">invalid image</a>. 
    <li> If the ID isn’t found in the map at all,
			it’s then looked for in the document as normal. 
   </ul>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-049385d0"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-049385d0"></a> This reuse of the ID selector matches Moz behavior.
		I’m trying to avoid slapping a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#identifier-value" id="ref-for-identifier-value">&lt;custom-ident></a> right in the beginning of the grammar,
		as that eats too much syntax-space.
		Another possibility, though, is to start the value with a language-defined keyword <em>followed by</em> a <span class="production" id="ref-for-identifier-value①">&lt;custom-ident></span>,
		like <span class="css">element(external fancy)</span> or something.
		Naming suggestions welcome. </p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-external-canvas">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-external-canvas"></a> For example, fancy animating backgrounds can be done with an external canvas: 
<pre class="lang-html highlight"><c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- a>var</c-> bg <c- o>=</c-> document<c- p>.</c->createElement<c- p>(</c-><c- t>'canvas'</c-><c- p>);</c->
bg<c- p>.</c->height <c- o>=</c-> <c- mf>200</c-><c- p>;</c->
bg<c- p>.</c->width <c- o>=</c-> <c- mf>1000</c-><c- p>;</c->
drawFancyBackground<c- p>(</c->bg<c- p>);</c->
CSS<c- p>.</c->elementSources<c- p>.</c->set<c- p>(</c-><c- t>'fancy'</c-><c- p>,</c-> bg<c- p>);</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>script</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- p>&lt;</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
<c- f>h1</c-> <c- p>{</c->
  <c- k>background-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>element</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- mh>#fancy</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- p>}</c->
<c- p>&lt;/</c-><c- f>style</c-><c- p>></c->
</pre>
    <p>As the "fancy" canvas is drawn into and animated,
		the backgrounds of all the H1 elements will automatically update in tandem.</p>
    <p>Note that the <a data-link-type="idl" href="#dom-css-elementsources" id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources④">elementSources</a> map is consulted <em>before</em> the document
		to match the ID selector,
		so even if there’s an element in the document that would match <span class="css">#fancy</span>,
		the backgrounds will still predictably come from the <span id="ref-for-dom-css-elementsources⑤">elementSources</span> value instead.</p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="2.7.3" id="element-cycles"><span class="secno">2.7.3. </span><span class="content"> Cycle Detection</span><a class="self-link" href="#element-cycles"></a></h4>
   <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⑧">element()</a> function can produce nonsensical circular relationships,
	such as an element using itself as its own background.
	These relationships can be easily and reliably detected and resolved, however,
	by keeping track of a dependency graph and using common cycle-detection algorithms.</p>
   <p>The dependency graph consists of edges such that:</p>
   <ul>
    <li> every element depends on its children 
    <li> for any element A with a property using the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element①⑨">element()</a> function pointing to an element B,
			A depends on B 
    <li> if a host language defines a way for elements to refer to the rendering of other elements,
			the referencing element depends on the referenced element.
			For example, in SVG,
			a <code class="highlight">&lt;use></code> element depends on the element it referenced. 
   </ul>
   <p>If the graph contains a cycle,
	any <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-element" id="ref-for-funcdef-element②⓪">element()</a> functions participating in the cycle are <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#invalid-image" id="ref-for-invalid-image⑨">invalid images</a>.</p>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="3" id="gradients"><span class="secno">3. </span><span class="content"> Gradients</span><a class="self-link" href="#gradients"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>A gradient is an image that smoothly fades from one color to another.
	These are commonly used for subtle shading in background images, buttons, and many other things.
	The <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="gradient function" id="gradient-function">gradient functions</dfn> described in this section allow an author to specify such an image in a terse syntax,
	so that the UA can generate the image automatically when rendering the page.
	The syntax of a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-gradient" id="ref-for-typedef-gradient①">&lt;gradient></a> is:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-gradient">&lt;gradient></dfn> = <c- p>[</c->
  <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient②">&lt;<c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one⑨">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-linear-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⓪">|</a>
  <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-radial-gradient">&lt;<c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①①">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-radial-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①②">|</a>
  <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-conic-gradient">&lt;<c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a>  <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①③">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> <c- p>]</c->
</pre>
   <div class="example" id="ex-gradients-are-images">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-gradients-are-images"></a> 
    <p>As with the other <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⑧">&lt;image></a> types defined in this specification,
		gradients can be used in any property that accepts images.
		For example:</p>
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->white<c- p>,</c-> gray<c- p>);</c-></code> 
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- k>list-style-image</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->circle<c- p>,</c-> #006<c- p>,</c-> #00a <c- m>90</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> #0000af <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c-></code> 
    </ul>
   </div>
   <p>A gradient is drawn into a box with the dimensions of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size⑧">concrete object size</a>,
	referred to as the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="gradient-box">gradient box</dfn>.
	However, the gradient itself has no <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions⑧">natural dimensions</a>.</p>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradients-with-border.html" title="css/css-images/gradients-with-border.html">gradients-with-border.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradients-with-border.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradients-with-border.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <div class="example" id="ex-default-gradient-box"><a class="self-link" href="#ex-default-gradient-box"></a> For example, if you use a gradient as a background,
		by default the gradient will draw into a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-box" id="ref-for-gradient-box">gradient box</a> the size of the element’s padding box.
		If <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-size" id="ref-for-propdef-background-size">background-size</a> is explicitly set to a value such as <span class="css">100px 200px</span>,
		then the <span id="ref-for-gradient-box①">gradient box</span> will be 100px wide and 200px tall.
		Similarly, for a gradient used as a <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-lists-3/#propdef-list-style-image" id="ref-for-propdef-list-style-image②">list-style-image</a>,
		the box would be a 1em square,
		which is the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#default-object-size" id="ref-for-default-object-size">default object size</a> for that property. </div>
   <p>Gradients are specified by defining the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport id="starting-point">starting point</dfn> and <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-noexport id="ending-point">ending point</dfn> of a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="gradient-line">gradient line</dfn> (which, depending on the type of gradient,
	may be technically a line, or a ray, or a spiral),
	and then specifying colors at points along this line.
	The colors are smoothly blended to fill in the rest of the line,
	and then each type of gradient defines how to use the color of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line">gradient line</a> to produce the actual gradient.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="3.1" id="linear-gradients"><span class="secno">3.1. </span><span class="content">Linear Gradients: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient③">linear-gradient()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#linear-gradients"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>This level adds a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> argument
	to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient④">linear-gradient()</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient①">repeating-linear-gradient()</a>,
	indicating the color space and path to use
	when interpolating colors on the gradient line.
	See <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#interpolation"><cite>CSS Color 4</cite> §  12. Color Interpolation</a>.</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-linear-gradient-syntax">&lt;linear-gradient-syntax></dfn> =
  <c- p>[</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value">&lt;angle></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①④">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#zero-value" id="ref-for-zero-value">&lt;zero></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⑤">|</a> to <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-side-or-corner" id="ref-for-typedef-side-or-corner">&lt;side-or-corner></a> <c- p>]</c-> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any①">||</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method①">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt⑤">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma①"><c- p>,</c-></a>
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-list" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-list">&lt;color-stop-list></a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-side-or-corner">&lt;side-or-corner></dfn> = <c- p>[</c->left <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⑥">|</a> right<c- p>]</c-> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any②">||</a> <c- p>[</c->top <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⑦">|</a> bottom<c- p>]</c->
</pre>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/color-stop-currentcolor.html" title="css/css-images/color-stop-currentcolor.html">color-stop-currentcolor.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/color-stop-currentcolor.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/color-stop-currentcolor.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-border-box.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-border-box.html">gradient-border-box.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-border-box.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-border-box.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-button.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-button.html">gradient-button.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-button.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-button.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html">gradient-content-box.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html"><small>(source)</small></a>

     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/linear-gradient-body-sibling-index.html" title="css/css-images/linear-gradient-body-sibling-index.html">linear-gradient-body-sibling-index.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/linear-gradient-body-sibling-index.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/linear-gradient-body-sibling-index.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/linear-gradient-calc-em-units.html" title="css/css-images/linear-gradient-calc-em-units.html">linear-gradient-calc-em-units.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/linear-gradient-calc-em-units.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/linear-gradient-calc-em-units.html"><small>(source)</small></a>

   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.1.1" id="color-interpolation"><span class="secno">3.1.1. </span><span class="content">Effects of color space on interpolation: examples</span><a class="self-link" href="#color-interpolation"></a></h4>
   <p><em>This section is non-normative.</em> </p>
   <p>The effect of colorspace on interpolation can be significant.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-colorspaces-srgb-lab-oklab">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-colorspaces-srgb-lab-oklab"></a> In this example, a linear gradient between the same pair of colors
	#f01 and #081 is drawn in three different colorspaces.
	The middle gradient uses gamma-encoded sRGB,
	which was the only choice in CSS Images 3;
	the result is clearly too dark at the midpoint.
	The upper gradient uses CIE Lab,
	giving a more perceptually uniform result;
	while the lower gradient uses Oklab,
	which here gives almost the same result as CIE Lab. 
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lab to right<c- p>,</c-> #F01<c- p>,</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in srgb to right<c- p>,</c-> #F01<c- p>,</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in Oklab to right<c- p>,</c-> #F01<c- p>,</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
    </ul>
    <p><img alt="red to green gradient in three colorspaces" height="330" src="images/rectangular-f01-081.png" width="360"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-colorspaces-blue-white">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-colorspaces-blue-white"></a> In this example, a linear gradient between the same pair of colors
	white and #01E is drawn in three different colorspaces.
	The middle gradient uses gamma-encoded sRGB,
	the result is again too dark at the midpoint,
	is a little desaturated, and has a slight purplish cast.
	The upper gradient uses CIE Lab,
	which avoids the too-dark midpoint
	but has a significant purple cast;
	while the lower gradient uses Oklab,
	giving a more perceptually uniform result
	with no purple cast at all. 
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lab to right<c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> #01E<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in srgb to right<c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> #01E<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in Oklab to right<c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> #01E<c- p>)</c-></code>
    </ul>
    <p><img alt="white to blue gradient in three colorspaces" height="330" src="images/rectangular-fff-01e.png" width="360"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-hue-nonlinearity">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-hue-nonlinearity"></a> In this example, a linear gradient between the same pair of colors
	#44C and #795 is drawn in three different colorspaces.
	This demonstrates that
	the hue non-linearity of CIE Lab
	affects all bulueish colors,
	not just the gradient from saturated primary blue to white.
	The middle gradient uses gamma-encoded sRGB,
	the result is again too dark at the midpoint,
	and has a slight purplish cast.
	The upper gradient uses CIE Lab,
	which avoids the too-dark midpoint
	but has a significant purple cast;
	while the lower gradient uses Oklab,
	again giving a more perceptually uniform result
	with no purple cast at all. 
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lab to right<c- p>,</c-> #44C<c- p>,</c-> #795<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in srgb to right<c- p>,</c-> #44C<c- p>,</c-> #795<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in Oklab to right<c- p>,</c-> #44C<c- p>,</c-> #795<c- p>)</c-></code>
    </ul>
    <p><img alt="blue to green gradient in three colorspaces" height="330" src="images/rectangular-44c-795.png" width="360"></p>
   </div>
   <p>Choosing a polar, rather than rectangular, colorspace
for gradient interpolation
avoids desaturation
if the hues of the color stops are far apart.
Interpolating in a polar colorspaces
is inherently chroma-preserving,
although it is easy for the intermediate colors to fall out of gamut;
they will then be gamut mapped
to bring them back into gamut.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-colorspaces-rectangular-polar">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-colorspaces-rectangular-polar"></a> In this example, a linear gradient between the same pair of colors
	#A37 and #595 is drawn in five different colorspaces,
	two of them polar.
	From top to bottom:
	CIE LCH, CIE Lab, sRGB, Oklab, Oklch. 
    <p>The rectangular spaces have a greyish midpoint,
	while the intermediate colors in the polar spaces
	follow a curved, chroma-preserving path.</p>
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lch to right<c- p>,</c-> #A37<c- p>,</c-> #595<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lab to right<c- p>,</c-> #A37<c- p>,</c-> #595<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in srgb to right<c- p>,</c-> #A37<c- p>,</c-> #595<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in Oklab to right<c- p>,</c-> #A37<c- p>,</c-> #595<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in oklch to right<c- p>,</c-> #A37<c- p>,</c-> #595<c- p>)</c-></code>
    </ul>
    <p><img alt="blue to green gradient in three colorspaces" height="538" src="images/polar-a37-595.png" width="360"></p>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="3.2" id="radial-gradients"><span class="secno">3.2. </span><span class="content">Radial Gradients: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-radial-gradient①">radial-gradient()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#radial-gradients"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.2.1" id="radial-color-interpolation"><span class="secno">3.2.1. </span><span class="content"> Adding <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method②">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a></span><a class="self-link" href="#radial-color-interpolation"></a></h4>
   <p>This level adds a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method③">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> argument
	to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-radial-gradient②">radial-gradient()</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient①">repeating-radial-gradient()</a>,
	indicating the color space and path to use
	when interpolating colors on the gradient line.
	See <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#interpolation"><cite>CSS Color 4</cite> §  12. Color Interpolation</a>.</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-radial-gradient-syntax">&lt;radial-gradient-syntax></dfn> =
  <c- p>[</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-shape" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-shape">&lt;radial-shape></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any③">||</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-size" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-size">&lt;radial-size></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt⑥">?</a> <c- p>[</c-> at <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-5/#typedef-position" id="ref-for-typedef-position">&lt;position></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt⑦">?</a> <c- p>]</c-> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any④">||</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method④">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a><c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt⑧">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma②"><c- p>,</c-></a>
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-list" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-list①">&lt;color-stop-list></a>
</pre>

   </details>
   <div class="example" id="ex-colorspaces-differ">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-colorspaces-differ"></a> In this example, a radial gradient between the same pair of colors
	color(display-p3 0.918 0.2 0.161) and #081 is drawn in three different colorspaces.
	Notice that the color stops do not all need to be in the same colorspace.
	The middle gradient uses gamma-encoded sRGB,
	the result is clearly too dark at the midpoint.
	The upper gradient uses CIE Lab,
	giving a more perceptually uniform result;
	while the lower gradient uses Oklab,
	which here gives almost the same result as CIE Lab. 
    <ul class="lang-css">
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in lab farthest-side at left bottom<c- p>,</c-> <c- nf>color</c-><c- p>(</c->display-p3 <c- m>0.918</c-> <c- m>0.2</c-> <c- m>0.161</c-><c- p>),</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in srgb farthest-side at left bottom<c- p>,</c-> <c- nf>color</c-><c- p>(</c->display-p3 <c- m>0.918</c-> <c- m>0.2</c-> <c- m>0.161</c-><c- p>),</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
     <li><code class="highlight"><c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in Oklab farthest-side at left bottom<c- p>,</c-> <c- nf>color</c-><c- p>(</c->display-p3 <c- m>0.918</c-> <c- m>0.2</c-> <c- m>0.161</c-><c- p>),</c-> #081<c- p>)</c-></code>
    </ul>
    <p><img alt="red to green gradient in three colorspaces" height="330" src="images/radial-rectangular-f01-081.png" width="360"></p>
   </div>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.2.2" id="radial-size"><span class="secno">3.2.2. </span><span class="content"> Expanding <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-size" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-size①">&lt;radial-size></a></span><a class="self-link" href="#radial-size"></a></h4>
   <p>This level extends the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-size" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-size②">&lt;radial-size></a> options
	to include the additions from the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-shapes-1/#funcdef-basic-shape-circle" id="ref-for-funcdef-basic-shape-circle">circle()</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-shapes-1/#funcdef-basic-shape-ellipse" id="ref-for-funcdef-basic-shape-ellipse">ellipse()</a> <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-shapes-1/#typedef-basic-shape" id="ref-for-typedef-basic-shape">&lt;basic-shape></a> values:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-size" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-size③">&lt;radial-size></a> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-extent" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-extent">&lt;radial-extent></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-num-range" id="ref-for-mult-num-range"><c- p>{</c-><c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>2</c-><c- p>}</c-></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⑧">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage">&lt;length-percentage <c- p>[</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c->∞<c- p>]</c->></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-num-range" id="ref-for-mult-num-range①"><c- p>{</c-><c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>2</c-><c- p>}</c-></a>
</pre>
   <p>Two-component values remain invalid when specifying <span class="css">circle</span> as the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-shape" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-shape①">&lt;radial-shape></a>,
	and otherwise indicate the horizontal (first) and vertical (second) radii
	of the ellipse.</p>
   <p>For <span class="css">circle</span>,
	a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value③">&lt;percentage></a> value is resolved against
	the “scaled diagonal” of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-box" id="ref-for-gradient-box②">gradient box</a>’s width and height: <code class="highlight"><c- nf>sqrt</c-><c- p>(</c->width² + height²<c- p>)</c->/<c- nf>sqrt</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>2</c-><c- p>)</c-></code>.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="3.3" id="conic-gradients"><span class="secno">3.3. </span><span class="content"> Conic Gradients: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-conic-gradient①">conic-gradient()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#conic-gradients"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>A conic gradient starts by specifying the center of a circle,
	similar to radial gradients,
	except that conic gradient color-stops are placed <em>around</em> the circumference of the circle,
	rather than on a line emerging from the center,
	causing the color to smoothly transition as you spin around the center,
	rather than as you progress outward from the center.</p>
   <p>A conic gradient is specified by indicating a rotation angle, the center of the gradient,
	and then specifying a list of color-stops.
	Unlike linear and radial gradients,
	whose color-stops are placed by specifying a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value①">&lt;length></a>,
	the color-stops of a conic gradient are specified with an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value①">&lt;angle></a>.
	Rays are then drawn emerging from the center and pointing in all directions,
	with the color of each ray equal to the color of the gradient-line where they intersect it.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> These gradients are called "conic" or "conical"
	because, if the color stops are chosen to be significantly lighter on one side than the other,
	it produces a pattern that looks like a cone observed from above.
	They are also known as "angle" gradients in some contexts,
	since they are produced by varying the rotation angle of a ray.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-simple-conic">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-simple-conic"></a> 
    <div style="overflow: hidden">
      <img alt="[An image showing a box with a background shading gradually clockwise from white to black, starting from the top. A gradient circle is shown, and the colors at 0 and 216 degrees respectively.]" height="300" src="images/conic-diagram.png" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em;" width="400"> 
     <p>This example visually illustrates how <span class="css">conic-gradient(at 25% 30%, white, black 60%)</span> would be drawn. Note that since color stop positions always resolve to angles, the only effect of the <span class="css">at 25% 30%</span> is a 2D translation of the gradient, i.e. it does not affect how the gradient is drawn.</p>
    </div>
   </div>
   <h4 class="no-toc heading settled" data-level="3.3.1" id="conic-gradient-syntax"><span class="secno">3.3.1. </span><span class="content"> <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-conic-gradient②">conic-gradient()</a> Syntax</span><a class="self-link" href="#conic-gradient-syntax"></a></h4>
   <p>The syntax for a conic gradient is:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-conic-gradient"><c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c-></dfn> = <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-conic-gradient-syntax" id="ref-for-typedef-conic-gradient-syntax">&lt;conic-gradient-syntax></a> <c- p>]</c-> <c- p>)</c->
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-conic-gradient-syntax">&lt;conic-gradient-syntax></dfn> =
  <c- p>[</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <c- p>[</c-> from <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value②">&lt;angle></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one①⑨">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#zero-value" id="ref-for-zero-value①">&lt;zero></a> <c- p>]</c-> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt⑨">?</a> <c- p>[</c-> at <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-5/#typedef-position" id="ref-for-typedef-position①">&lt;position></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⓪">?</a> <c- p>]</c-> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any⑤">||</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method⑤">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①①">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma③"><c- p>,</c-></a>
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-angular-color-stop-list" id="ref-for-typedef-angular-color-stop-list">&lt;angular-color-stop-list></a>
</pre>
   <p>The arguments are defined as follows:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="conic-gradient(), repeating-conic-gradient()" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-conic-gradient-angle--zero"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value③">&lt;angle></a> | <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#zero-value" id="ref-for-zero-value②">&lt;zero></a></dfn> 
    <dd> The entire gradient is rotated by this angle.
			If omitted, defaults to <span class="css">0deg</span>.
			The unit identifier may be omitted if the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value④">&lt;angle></a> is zero. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="conic-gradient(), repeating-conic-gradient()" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-conic-gradient-position"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-5/#typedef-position" id="ref-for-typedef-position②">&lt;position></a></dfn> 
    <dd> Determines the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-for="conic-gradient(), repeating-conic-gradient()" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="conic-gradient-gradient-center">gradient center</dfn> of the gradient.
			The <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-5/#typedef-position" id="ref-for-typedef-position③">&lt;position></a> value type (which is also used for <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-position" id="ref-for-propdef-background-position">background-position</a>)
			is defined in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-values-3" title="CSS Values and Units Module Level 3">[CSS-VALUES-3]</a>,
			and is resolved using the center-point as the object area
			and the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-box" id="ref-for-gradient-box③">gradient box</a> as the positioning area.
			If this argument is omitted, it defaults to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#valdef-background-position-center" id="ref-for-valdef-background-position-center">center</a>. 
   </dl>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-c602e287"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-c602e287"></a> Usually in conic gradients the sharp transition at 0deg is undesirable, which is typically avoided by making sure the first and last color stops are the same color. Perhaps it would be useful to have a keyword for automatically achieving this. </p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-e52a09ba"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-e52a09ba"></a> Would a radius (inner &amp; outer) for clipping the gradient be useful? If so, we could also support lengths in color stop positions, since we now have a specific radius. </p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-51674aed"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-51674aed"></a> Are elliptical conic gradients useful? Do graphics libraries support them?</p>

   <h4 class="no-toc heading settled" data-level="3.3.2" id="conic-color-stops"><span class="secno">3.3.2. </span><span class="content"> Placing Color Stops</span><a class="self-link" href="#conic-color-stops"></a></h4>
   <p>Color stops are placed on a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line①">gradient line</a> that curves around the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#conic-gradient-gradient-center" id="ref-for-conic-gradient-gradient-center">gradient center</a> in a circle,
	with both the 0% and 100% locations at 0deg.
	Just like linear gradients,
	0deg points to the top of the page,
	and increasing angles correspond to clockwise movement around the circle.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> It may be more helpful to think of the gradient line as forming a spiral,
	where only the segment from 0deg to 360deg is rendered.
	This avoids any confusion about "overlap" when you have angles outside of the rendered region.</p>
   <p>A color-stop can be placed at a location before 0% or after 100%;
	though these regions are never directly consulted for rendering,
	color stops placed there can affect the color of color-stops within the rendered region
	through interpolation or repetition (see <a href="#repeating-gradients">repeating gradients</a>).
	For example, <span class="css">conic-gradient(red -50%, yellow 150%)</span> produces a conic gradient
	that starts with a reddish-orange color at 0deg (specifically, #f50),
	and transitions to an orangish-yellow color at 360deg (specifically, #fa0).</p>
   <p>The color of the gradient at any point is determined by first finding the unique ray
	anchored at the center of the gradient that passes through the given point.
	The point’s color is then the color of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line②">gradient line</a> at the location where this ray intersects it.</p>
   <h4 class="no-toc heading settled" data-level="3.3.3" id="conic-gradient-examples"><span class="secno">3.3.3. </span><span class="content"> Conic Gradient Examples</span><a class="self-link" href="#conic-gradient-examples"></a></h4>
   <p>All of the following <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-conic-gradient③">conic-gradient()</a> examples are presumed to be applied to a box that is 300px wide and 200px tall, unless otherwise specified.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-conic-syntax">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-conic-syntax"></a> Below are various ways of specifying the same basic conic gradient: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->#f06<c- p>,</c-> gold<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->at <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> #f06<c- p>,</c-> gold<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->from <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> #f06<c- p>,</c-> gold<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->from <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> at center<c- p>,</c-> #f06<c- p>,</c-> gold<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->#f06 <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> gold <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->#f06 <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> gold <c- m>1</c-><c- k>turn</c-><c- p>);</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/conic1.png" width="300"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-conic-angles">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-conic-angles"></a> Below are various ways of specifying the same basic conic gradient.
		This demonstrates how even though color stops with angles outside [0deg, 360deg) are not directly painted,
		they can still affect the color of the painted part of the gradient. 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->white <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>150</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->white <c- m>-180</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>540</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- nf>hsl</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>75</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>),</c-> <c- nf>hsl</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>25</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>));</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/conic2.png" width="300"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-conic-rotated">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-conic-rotated"></a> Below are two different ways of specifying the same rotated conic gradient, one with a rotation angle and one without: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->from <c- m>45</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> black<c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- nf>hsl</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>75</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>),</c-> white <c- m>45</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>225</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- nf>hsl</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>75</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>));</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/conic3.png" width="300"></p>
    <p>Note that offsetting every color stop by the rotation angle instead would not work and produces an entirely different gradient:</p>
<pre class="highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->white <c- m>45</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>225</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>405</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>);</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/conic4.png" width="300"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-hsl-wheel">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-hsl-wheel"></a> A conic gradient with a radial gradient overlaid on it, to draw a hue &amp; saturation wheel: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->closest-side<c- p>,</c-> gray<c- p>,</c-> transparent<c- p>),</c->
            <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red<c- p>,</c-> magenta<c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>,</c-> aqua<c- p>,</c-> lime<c- p>,</c-> yellow<c- p>,</c-> red<c- p>);</c->
<c- k>border-radius</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- k>width</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>height</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p>You can also achieve the same effect using "longer" hue interpolation. This is more concise and makes it easy to switch to other color spaces.</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->closest-side<c- p>,</c-> gray<c- p>,</c-> transparent<c- p>),</c->
            <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in hsl longer hue<c- p>,</c-> red <c- m>0</c-> <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>transform</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>scaleX</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>-1</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>border-radius</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- k>width</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>height</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt="color wheel" height="200" src="images/conic5.png" width="200"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-conic-pie">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-conic-pie"></a> A conic gradient used to draw a simple pie chart.
		The <span class="css">0deg</span> color stop positions will be fixed up to be equal to the position of the color stop before them.
		This will produce infinitesimal (invisible) transitions between the color stops with different colors,
		effectively producing solid color segments. 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->yellowgreen <c- m>40</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> gold <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>75</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> #f06 <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>border-radius</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- k>width</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c-> <c- k>height</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>200</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="202" src="images/conic6.png" width="202"></p>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="3.4" id="repeating-gradients"><span class="secno">3.4. </span><span class="content"> Repeating Gradients: the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient②">repeating-linear-gradient()</a>, <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient②">repeating-radial-gradient()</a>, and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient①">repeating-conic-gradient()</a> notations</span><a class="self-link" href="#repeating-gradients"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>In addition to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient⑤">linear-gradient()</a>, <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-radial-gradient③">radial-gradient()</a>, and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-conic-gradient④">conic-gradient()</a>,
	this specification defines <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient">repeating-linear-gradient()</dfn>, <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient">repeating-radial-gradient()</dfn>,
	and <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient">repeating-conic-gradient()</dfn> values.
	These notations take the same values
	and are interpreted the same
	as their respective non-repeating siblings defined previously.</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-conic-gradient②">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> = <c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-conic-gradient-syntax" id="ref-for-typedef-conic-gradient-syntax①">&lt;conic-gradient-syntax></a> <c- p>]</c-> <c- p>)</c->
<a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient③">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-linear-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> = <c- nf>repeating-linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-linear-gradient-syntax" id="ref-for-typedef-linear-gradient-syntax">&lt;linear-gradient-syntax></a> <c- p>]</c-> <c- p>)</c->
<a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-radial-gradient③">&lt;<c- nf>repeating-radial-gradient</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> = <c- nf>repeating-radial-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-radial-gradient-syntax" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-gradient-syntax">&lt;radial-gradient-syntax></a> <c- p>]</c-> <c- p>)</c->
</pre>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html">gradient-content-box.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-content-box.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html" title="css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html">color-stops-parsing.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient/repeating-gradient-hsl-and-oklch.html" title="css/css-images/gradient/repeating-gradient-hsl-and-oklch.html">repeating-gradient-hsl-and-oklch.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient/repeating-gradient-hsl-and-oklch.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient/repeating-gradient-hsl-and-oklch.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <div class="example" id="ex-conic-repeat">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-conic-repeat"></a> Basic repeating conic gradient: 
<pre class="highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->gold<c- p>,</c-> #f06 <c- m>20</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>);</c-></pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/repeating-conic1.png" width="300"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-gradient-starburst">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-gradient-starburst"></a> Repeating color stops with abrupt transitions creates a starburst-type background: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->
                <c- nf>hsla</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>.2</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>15</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>,</c->
                <c- nf>hsla</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>30</c-><c- k>deg</c->
            <c- p>)</c-> #0ac<c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/repeating-conic2.png" width="300"></p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-checkerboards">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-checkerboards"></a> Here repeating color stops with abrupt transitions are used to create a checkerboard: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>repeating-conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->black <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>25</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background-size</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>60</c-><c- k>px</c-> <c- m>60</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c->
</pre>
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/repeating-conic3.png" width="300"></p>
    <p>The same checkerboard can be created via non-repeating conic gradients:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>conic-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->black <c- m>25</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-> <c- m>75</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>deg</c-><c- p>);</c->
<c- k>background-size</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>60</c-><c- k>px</c-> <c- m>60</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>;</c->
</pre>
   </div>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="3.5" id="gradient-colors"><span class="secno">3.5. </span><span class="content">Defining Gradient Color</span><a class="self-link" href="#gradient-colors"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The colors in gradients are specified using <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="color stop" id="color-stop">color stops</dfn> (a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①⓪">&lt;color></a> and a corresponding position on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line③">gradient line</a>)
	and <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-local-lt="transition hint" data-lt="color transition hint" id="color-transition-hint">color transition hints</dfn> (a position between two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop">color stops</a> representing the halfway point in the color transition)
	which are placed on the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line④">gradient line</span>,
	defining the color at every point of the line.
	(Each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-function" id="ref-for-gradient-function">gradient function</a> defines the shape and length of the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line⑤">gradient line</span>,
	along with its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#starting-point" id="ref-for-starting-point">starting point</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#ending-point" id="ref-for-ending-point">ending point</a>;
	see above.)</p>
   <p>Colors throughout the gradient field are then determined
	by tying them to specific points along the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line⑥">gradient line</a> as specified by the gradient function.
	UAs may “dither” gradient colors slightly
	(randomly alternate individual pixels with nearby colors on the gradient line)
	to effect a smoother gradient.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.5.1" id="color-stop-syntax"><span class="secno">3.5.1. </span><span class="content"> Color Stop Lists</span><a class="self-link" href="#color-stop-syntax"></a></h4>
   <p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop①">Color stops</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint">transition hints</a> are specified
	in a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="color-stop-list">color stop list</dfn>,
	which is a list of one or more <span id="ref-for-color-stop②">color stops</span> interleaved with optional <span id="ref-for-color-transition-hint①">transition hints</span>:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight"><dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-color-stop-list">&lt;color-stop-list></dfn> =
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-linear-color-stop" id="ref-for-typedef-linear-color-stop">&lt;linear-color-stop></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma④"><c- p>,</c-></a> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-linear-color-hint" id="ref-for-typedef-linear-color-hint">&lt;linear-color-hint></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①②">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma⑤"><c- p>,</c-></a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-linear-color-stop" id="ref-for-typedef-linear-color-stop①">&lt;linear-color-stop></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma②">#</a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①③">?</a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-linear-color-stop">&lt;linear-color-stop></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①①">&lt;color></a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-length" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-length">&lt;color-stop-length></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①④">?</a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-linear-color-hint">&lt;linear-color-hint></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage①">&lt;length-percentage></a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-color-stop-length">&lt;color-stop-length></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage②">&lt;length-percentage></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-num-range" id="ref-for-mult-num-range②"><c- p>{</c-><c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>2</c-><c- p>}</c-></a>

<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-angular-color-stop-list">&lt;angular-color-stop-list></dfn> =
  <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-angular-color-stop" id="ref-for-typedef-angular-color-stop">&lt;angular-color-stop></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma⑥"><c- p>,</c-></a> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-angular-color-hint" id="ref-for-typedef-angular-color-hint">&lt;angular-color-hint></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⑤">?</a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-comma" id="ref-for-comb-comma⑦"><c- p>,</c-></a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-angular-color-stop" id="ref-for-typedef-angular-color-stop①">&lt;angular-color-stop></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma③">#</a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⑥">?</a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-angular-color-stop">&lt;angular-color-stop></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①②">&lt;color></a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-angle" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-angle">&lt;color-stop-angle></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⑦">?</a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-angular-color-hint">&lt;angular-color-hint></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-angle-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-angle-percentage">&lt;angle-percentage></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②⓪">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#zero-value" id="ref-for-zero-value③">&lt;zero></a>
<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-color-stop-angle">&lt;color-stop-angle></dfn> = <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-angle-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-angle-percentage①">&lt;angle-percentage></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②①">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#zero-value" id="ref-for-zero-value④">&lt;zero></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-num-range" id="ref-for-mult-num-range③"><c- p>{</c-><c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>2</c-><c- p>}</c-></a>

<dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-color-stop">&lt;color-stop></dfn> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-length" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-length①">&lt;color-stop-length></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②②">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-angle" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-angle①">&lt;color-stop-angle></a>
</pre>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html" title="css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html">color-stops-parsing.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient/color-stops-parsing.html"><small>(source)</small></a>

   </details>
   <div class="note" role="note">
     Note that <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop-list" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop-list②">&lt;color-stop-list></a> and <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-angular-color-stop-list" id="ref-for-typedef-angular-color-stop-list①">&lt;angular-color-stop-list></a> are exactly identical in structure,
		they just differ on whether they accept <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value②">&lt;length></a>s or <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value⑤">&lt;angle></a>s
		for specifying the position of the stops and hints. 
    <p>Visualized with a railroad diagram,
		both of them follow this pattern:</p>
    <div class="railroad">
