   </div>
   <p>A <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop③">color stop</a> with two positions is equivalent
	to specifying two <span id="ref-for-color-stop④">color stops</span> with the same color,
	one for each position.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Usually, this results in a solid-color "stripe"
	between the two positions,
	but using a <span class="css">longer</span> <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method⑥">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> will instead create a "rainbow" between the two positions.</p>
   <p>Percentages are resolved against the length of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line⑦">gradient line</a> between the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#starting-point" id="ref-for-starting-point①">starting point</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#ending-point" id="ref-for-ending-point①">ending point</a>,
	with 0% being at the starting point
	and 100% being at the ending point.
	Lengths are measured along the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line⑧">gradient line</span> from the <span id="ref-for-starting-point②">starting point</span> in the direction of the <span id="ref-for-ending-point②">ending point</span>.</p>
   <p><a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop⑤">Color stop</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint②">transition hint</a> positions
	are usually placed between
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#starting-point" id="ref-for-starting-point③">starting point</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#ending-point" id="ref-for-ending-point③">ending point</a>,
	but that’s not required:
	the gradient line extends infinitely in both directions,
	and positions can be specified anywhere
	on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line⑨">gradient line</a>.</p>
   <p>When the position of a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop⑥">color stop</a> is omitted,
	it is automatically assigned a position.
	The first or last <span id="ref-for-color-stop⑦">color stop</span> in the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop-list" id="ref-for-color-stop-list">color stop list</a> is assigned
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line①⓪">gradient line’s</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#starting-point" id="ref-for-starting-point④">starting point</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#ending-point" id="ref-for-ending-point④">ending point</a> (respectively).
	Otherwise,
	it’s assigned the position halfway between the two surrounding stops.
	If multiple stops in a row lack a position,
	they space themselves out equally
	between the surrounding positioned stops.
	See <a href="#color-stop-fixup">§ 3.5.3 Color Stop “Fixup”</a> for details.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.5.2" id="coloring-gradient-line"><span class="secno">3.5.2. </span><span class="content"> Coloring the Gradient Line</span><a class="self-link" href="#coloring-gradient-line"></a></h4>
   <p>At each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop⑧">color stop</a> position,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#gradient-line" id="ref-for-gradient-line①①">gradient line</a> is the color of the <span id="ref-for-color-stop⑨">color stop</span>.
	Before the first <span id="ref-for-color-stop①⓪">color stop</span>,
	the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line①②">gradient line</span> is the color of the first <span id="ref-for-color-stop①①">color stop</span>,
	and after the last <span id="ref-for-color-stop①②">color stop</span>,
	the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line①③">gradient line</span> is the color of the last <span id="ref-for-color-stop①③">color stop</span>.
	Between each pair of <span id="ref-for-color-stop①④">color stops</span>,
	the <span id="ref-for-gradient-line①④">gradient line’s</span> color is interpolated between the colors of the two <span id="ref-for-color-stop①⑤">color stops</span>,
	with the interpolation taking place in the specified color space,
	with missing components handled as defined in <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#interpolation-missing"><cite>CSS Color 4</cite> § 12.2 Interpolating with Missing Components</a>,
	hue interpolation as defined in <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#hue-interpolation"><cite>CSS Color 4</cite> § 12.4 Hue Interpolation</a>, and
	using premultiplied alpha, as defined in <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#interpolation-alpha"><cite>CSS Color 4</cite> § 12.3 Interpolating with Alpha</a>.
	If no <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method⑦">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> is specified in the gradient function,
	the color space used for gradient interpolation
	is the default interpolation color space, Oklab, as defined in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-css-color-4" title="CSS Color Module Level 4">[css-color-4]</a>.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#color-interpolation-method" id="ref-for-color-interpolation-method⑧">&lt;color-interpolation-method></a> only affects the colors <em>between</em> stops.
	The color before the first and after the last stop
	is equal to the first/last stop, <em>regardless</em> of the interpolation method.</p>

     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient/gradient-powerless-hue-oklch.html" title="css/css-images/gradient/gradient-powerless-hue-oklch.html">gradient-powerless-hue-oklch.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient/gradient-powerless-hue-oklch.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient/gradient-powerless-hue-oklch.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <div class="example" id="ex-missing-hue">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-missing-hue"></a> For example, given the following gradient definition: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->in oklch<c- p>,</c-> red<c- p>,</c-> #888<c- p>,</c-> green<c- p>)</c->
</pre>
    <p>the conversion of the neutral #888 to oklch
		gives a missing hue component: <span class="lang-css">oklch(0.6268 0 none)</span></p>
    <p>and thus, in the first gradient segment,
		the hue is taken from red, 
		which is <span class="lang-css">oklch(0.628 0.2577 29.234)</span>;
		while in the second segment 
		it is taken from green,
		which is <span class="lang-css">oklch(0.5198 0.1769 142.5)</span></p>
   </div>
   <p>By default,
	this interpolation is linear—​at 25%, 50%, or 75% of the distance between two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop①⑥">color stops</a>,
	the color is a 25%, 50%, or 75% blend of the colors of the two stops.</p>
   <p>However, if a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint③">transition hint</a> was provided between two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop①⑦">color stops</a>,
	the interpolation is non-linear,
	and controlled by the hint:</p>
   <div class="algorithm" data-algorithm="interpolate with a color hint">
    <ol>
     <li> Determine the location of the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint④">transition hint</a> as a percentage of the distance between the two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop①⑧">color stops</a>,
				denoted as a number between 0 and 1,
				where 0 indicates the hint is placed right on the first <span id="ref-for-color-stop①⑨">color stop</span>,
				and 1 indicates the hint is placed right on the second <span id="ref-for-color-stop②⓪">color stop</span>.
				Let this percentage be <var>H</var>. 
     <li> For any given point between the two color stops,
				determine the point’s location as a percentage of the distance between the two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②①">color stops</a>,
				in the same way as the previous step.
				Let this percentage be <var>P</var>. 
     <li> Let <var>C</var>, the color weighting at that point,
				be equal to <code class="highlight"><var><c- nf>P</c-></var><sup><c- nf>log</c-><sub><var><c- nf>H</c-></var></sub><c- p>(</c-><c- m>.5</c-><c- p>)</c-></sup></code>. 
     <li> The color at that point is then a linear blend between the colors of the two <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②②">color stops</a>,
				blending <code class="highlight"><c- p>(</c-><c- m>1</c-> - <var>C</var><c- p>)</c-></code> of the first stop and <var>C</var> of the second stop. 
    </ol>
   </div>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint⑤">transition hint</a> specifies where the “halfway color”—​the 50% blend between the colors of the two surrounding color stops—​should be placed.
	When the hint is exactly halfway between the two surrounding color stops,
	the above interpolation algorithm
	happens to produce the ordinary linear interpolation.
	If the hint is placed anywhere else,
	it produces a smooth exponential curve
	between the surrounding color stops,
	with the “halfway color” occurring exactly where the hint specifies.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-transition-hints">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-transition-hints"></a> Here an example of a linear gradient without <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint⑥">transition hint</a> (top) compared to one with a transition hint between the red and blue <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②③">color stops</a> (bottom). 
    <p><img alt height="200" src="images/gradient-colors-transition-hint-comparison.png" width="300"></p>
    <p>Top - Without transition hint (falling back to the default halfway transition hint):</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->to right<c- p>,</c-> red <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
</pre>
    <p>Bottom - With transition hint:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight"><c- k>background</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->to right<c- p>,</c-> red <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>25</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>);</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <p>If multiple <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②④">color stops</a> have the same position,
	they produce an infinitesimal transition from the one specified first in the list
	to the one specified last.
	In effect, the color suddenly changes at that position rather than smoothly transitioning.</p>
   <h4 class="heading settled" data-level="3.5.3" id="color-stop-fixup"><span class="secno">3.5.3. </span><span class="content"> Color Stop “Fixup”</span><a class="self-link" href="#color-stop-fixup"></a></h4>
   <p>When resolving the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade-5/#used-value" id="ref-for-used-value">used</a> positions of each <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②⑤">color stop</a>,
	the following steps must be applied <em>in order</em>:</p>
   <ol>
    <li> If the first <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②⑥">color stop</a> does not have a position,
			set its position to 0%. 
    <li> If the last <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②⑦">color stop</a> does not have a position,
			set its position to 100%. 
    <li> If a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop②⑧">color stop</a> or <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint⑦">transition hint</a> has a position
			that is less than the specified position
			of any <span id="ref-for-color-stop②⑨">color stop</span> or <span id="ref-for-color-transition-hint⑧">transition hint</span> before it in the list,
			set its position to be equal to the largest specified position
			of any <span id="ref-for-color-stop③⓪">color stop</span> or <span id="ref-for-color-transition-hint⑨">transition hint</span> before it. 
    <li> If any <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop③①">color stop</a> still does not have a position,
			then, for each run of adjacent <span id="ref-for-color-stop③②">color stops</span> without positions,
			set their positions so that they are evenly spaced
			between the preceding and following <span id="ref-for-color-stop③③">color stops</span> with positions. 
   </ol>
   <p>After applying these rules,
	all <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop③④">color stops</a> and <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-transition-hint" id="ref-for-color-transition-hint①⓪">transition hints</a> will have a definite position and color
	and they will be in ascending order.</p>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-move-stops.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-move-stops.html">gradient-move-stops.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-move-stops.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-move-stops.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-nan-crash.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-nan-crash.html">gradient-nan-crash.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-nan-crash.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-nan-crash.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/gradient-refcrash.html" title="css/css-images/gradient-refcrash.html">gradient-refcrash.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/gradient-refcrash.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/gradient-refcrash.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> It is recommended that authors exercise caution
	when mixing different types of units,
	such as px, em, or %,
	as this can cause a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#color-stop" id="ref-for-color-stop③⑤">color stop</a> to unintentionally try to move before an earlier one.
	For example,
	the rule <a class="css" data-link-type="propdesc" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-image" id="ref-for-propdef-background-image①">background-image: linear-gradient(yellow 100px, blue 50%)</a> wouldn’t trigger any fix-up while the background area is at least <span class="css">200px</span> tall.
	If it was <span class="css">150px</span> tall, however,
	the blue <span id="ref-for-color-stop③⑥">color stop’s</span> position would be equivalent to <span class="css">75px</span>,
	which precedes the yellow <span id="ref-for-color-stop③⑦">color stop</span>,
	and would be corrected to a position of <span class="css">100px</span>.
	Additionally, since the relative ordering of such color stops
	cannot be determined without performing layout,
	they will not interpolate smoothly in <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-animations/">animations</a> or <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-transitions/">transitions</a>.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-gradient-fixup">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-gradient-fixup"></a> Below are several pairs of gradients.
		The latter of each pair is a manually “fixed-up” version of the former,
		obtained by applying the above rules.
		For each pair, both gradients will render identically. <span class="note">The numbers in each arrow specify which fixup steps are invoked in the transformation.</span> 
<pre class="highlight"><c- m>1</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red<c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>20</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>1</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>20</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>2</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>40</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> black<c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>3</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>40</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>60</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>80</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>3</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>3</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>25</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>4</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white<c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>3</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- nf>calc</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>-25</c-><c- k>px</c-> + <c- m>50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>),</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>5</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>20</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>40</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>2</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>20</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>20</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>40</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>6</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red<c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>-50</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>150</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue<c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>1</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>2</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>150</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>150</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>)</c->

<c- m>7</c->. <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>80</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>0</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> black<c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c->
   =<c- m>2</c-><c- p>,</c-><c- m>3</c->=>
   <c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c->red <c- m>80</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> white <c- m>80</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> black <c- m>90</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>,</c-> blue <c- m>100</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c->
</pre>
   </div>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="4" id="stripes"><span class="secno">4. </span><span class="content">1D Image Values: the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-1d" id="ref-for-typedef-image-1d">&lt;image-1D></a> type and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes">stripes()</a> notation</span><a class="self-link" href="#stripes"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>While <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image①⑨">&lt;image></a> values represent a 2-dimensional (2D) image,
	and <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①③">&lt;color></a> can be thought of as a 0-dimensional (0D) image
	(unvarying in either axis),
	some contexts require a <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export data-lt="1D image | one-dimensional image | 1-dimensional image" id="1d-image">1-dimensional (1D) image</dfn>,
	which specifies colors along an abstract, directionless, single-axis <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="paint-line">paint line</dfn>.
	The <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-image-1d"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image-1d" id="ref-for-typedef-image-1d①">&lt;image-1D></a></dfn> type represents such <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#1d-image" id="ref-for-1d-image">1D images</a>,
	including the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes①">stripes()</a> <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#functional-notation" id="ref-for-functional-notation">functional notation</a>:</p>
<pre class="prod highlight">&lt;image-1D> = <a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes②">&lt;<c- nf>stripes</c-><c- p>()</c->></a>
<a class="production" data-link-type="function" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes③">&lt;<c- nf>stripes</c-><c- p>()</c->></a> = <c- nf>stripes</c-><c- p>(</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stripe" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stripe">&lt;color-stripe></a><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-comma" id="ref-for-mult-comma④">#</a> <c- p>)</c->
<a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stripe" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stripe①">&lt;color-stripe></a> = <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①④">&lt;color></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-all" id="ref-for-comb-all①">&amp;&amp;</a> <c- p>[</c-> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage③">&lt;length-percentage></a> <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②③">|</a> <a class="production" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex">&lt;flex></a> <c- p>]</c-><a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⑧">?</a>
</pre>
   <p>The <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef-stripes">stripes()</dfn> function defines a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#1d-image" id="ref-for-1d-image①">1D image</a> as a comma-separated list of colored stripes,
	each placed end-to-end on the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-line" id="ref-for-paint-line">paint line</a> in the order given.</p>
   <p>Each <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="type" data-export id="typedef-color-stripe"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stripe" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stripe②">&lt;color-stripe></a></dfn> entry defines a solid-color stripe
	with the specified <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#typedef-color" id="ref-for-typedef-color①⑤">&lt;color></a> and thickness.
	If the thickness is omitted,
	it defaults to <span class="css">1fr</span>.
	Thickness values are interpreted as follows:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="stripes()" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-stripes-percentage-0-100"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value④">&lt;percentage [0,100]></a></dfn> 
    <dd> Percentage thicknesses are relative to the <var>total width</var>.
			Only values between <span class="css">0%</span> and <span class="css">100%</span> (inclusive)
			are valid. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="stripes()" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-stripes-length-0"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value③">&lt;length [0,∞]></a></dfn> 
    <dd> Negative length values are invalid. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="stripes()" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-stripes-flex"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex①">&lt;flex></a></dfn> 
    <dd> A <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex②">&lt;flex></a> is evaluated as a fraction of the <var>total width</var> relative to the total sum of <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-flex③">&lt;flex></span> entries in the function,
			after subtracting the thickness of any non-<span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-flex④">&lt;flex></span> entries
			(flooring the subtraction result at zero).
			If the sum of <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-flex⑤">&lt;flex></span> values is less than <span class="css">1fr</span>,
			the result of the subtraction is multiplied by the sum’s value
			before being distributed. 
   </dl>
   <p>The <var>total width</var> is defined by the context in which the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes④">stripes()</a> function is used.
	If the sum of the stripes is smaller than the <var>total width</var>,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#paint-line" id="ref-for-paint-line①">paint line</a> is <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#transparent-black" id="ref-for-transparent-black">transparent black</a> for its remaining length,
	as if a final <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#valdef-color-transparent" id="ref-for-valdef-color-transparent④">transparent</a> argument were given.
	If the sum is larger,
	any stripes or portions beyond the <var>total width</var> are truncated.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-stripes-total-width">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-stripes-total-width"></a> For example, <span class="css">stripes(red 1fr, green 2fr, blue 100px)</span> with a <var>total width</var> of <span class="css">400px</span> will result in a 100px red stripe and 200px green stripe,
		giving red 1 share and green 2 shares of the 300px remaining
		after subtracting blue’s 100px from the 400px total. 
    <p><img alt src="images/stripes1.svg" style="height:1em; width:400px;"></p>
    <p>On the other hand, <span class="css">stripes(red .1fr, green .2fr, blue 100px)</span> with a <var>total width</var> of <span class="css">400px</span> will instead give a 30px red stripe and 60px green stripe,
		followed by 100px of blue and then 210px of transparent.
		The 300px of leftover space is multiplied by .3,
		the value of the sum of the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex⑥">&lt;flex></a> values,
		to obtain only 90px,
		which is then distributed in the 1:2 ratio
		dictated by the <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-flex⑦">&lt;flex></span> values.</p>
    <p><img alt src="images/stripes2.svg" style="height:1em; width:400px;"></p>
    <p>(This is similar to how <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-flexbox-1/#flex-layout" id="ref-for-flex-layout">flex layout</a> deals with small <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex⑧">&lt;flex></a> sums on a line,
		and ensures smoothly continuous behavior
		as the <span class="production" id="ref-for-typedef-flex⑨">&lt;flex></span> values approach zero.)</p>
   </div>
   <p>The <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade-5/#computed-value" id="ref-for-computed-value①">computed value</a> of this function is
	an ordered list of stripes,
	each given as a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/#computed-color" id="ref-for-computed-color">computed color</a> and a thickness represented either a <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex①⓪">&lt;flex></a> value
	or a computed <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage④">&lt;length-percentage></a> value.</p>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="5" id="sizing"><span class="secno">5. </span><span class="content">Sizing Images and Objects in CSS</span><a class="self-link" href="#sizing"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>



</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="5.1" id="the-object-fit"><span class="secno">5.1. </span><span class="content">Sizing Objects: the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-object-fit" id="ref-for-propdef-object-fit">object-fit</a> property</span><a class="self-link" href="#the-object-fit"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<table class="def propdef" data-link-for-hint="object-fit">
    <tbody>
     <tr>
      <th>Name:
      <td><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="property" data-export id="propdef-object-fit">object-fit</dfn>
     <tr class="value">
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values/#value-defs">Value:</a>
      <td class="prod">fill <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-one" id="ref-for-comb-one②④">|</a> none <span id="ref-for-comb-one②⑤">|</span> [contain <span id="ref-for-comb-one②⑥">|</span> cover] <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any⑥">||</a> scale-down 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#initial-values">Initial:</a>
      <td>fill 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#applies-to">Applies to:</a>
      <td>replaced elements 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#inherited-property">Inherited:</a>
      <td>no 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values/#percentages">Percentages:</a>
      <td>n/a 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#computed">Computed value:</a>
      <td>specified keyword(s) 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom/#serializing-css-values">Canonical order:</a>
      <td>per grammar 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/web-animations/#animation-type">Animation type:</a>
      <td>discrete 
   </table>
   <p>The <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-object-fit" id="ref-for-propdef-object-fit①">object-fit</a> property specifies how the contents of a replaced element
	should be fitted to the box established by its used height and width.</p>
   <dl>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="object-fit" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-object-fit-fill">fill</dfn> 
    <dd> The replaced content is sized to fill the element’s content box:
			the object’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size⑨">concrete object size</a> is the element’s used width and height. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="object-fit" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-object-fit-none">none</dfn> 
    <dd> The replaced content is not resized to fit inside the element’s content box:
			determine the object’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①⓪">concrete object size</a> using the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#default-sizing-algorithm" id="ref-for-default-sizing-algorithm">default sizing algorithm</a> with no specified size,
			and a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#default-object-size" id="ref-for-default-object-size①">default object size</a> equal to the replaced element’s used width and height. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="object-fit" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-object-fit-contain">contain</dfn> 
    <dd>
      The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio
			while fitting within the element’s content box:
			its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①①">concrete object size</a> is resolved as a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#contain-constraint" id="ref-for-contain-constraint">contain constraint</a> against the element’s used width and height. 
     <p>If the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-scale-down" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-scale-down">scale-down</a> flag is used, size the content as if <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-none" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-none">none</a> or <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-contain" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-contain">contain</a> were specified,
			whichever would result in a smaller <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①②">concrete object size</a>.</p>
     <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Both <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-none" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-none①">none</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-contain" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-contain①">contain</a> respect the content’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-aspect-ratio" id="ref-for-natural-aspect-ratio">natural aspect ratio</a>,
			so the concept of "smaller" is well-defined.</p>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="object-fit" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-object-fit-cover">cover</dfn> 
    <dd>
      The replaced content is sized to maintain its aspect ratio
			while filling the element’s entire content box:
			its <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①③">concrete object size</a> is resolved as a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#cover-constraint" id="ref-for-cover-constraint">cover constraint</a> against the element’s used width and height. 
     <p>If the <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-scale-down" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-scale-down①">scale-down</a> flag is used, size the content as if <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-none" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-none②">none</a> or <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-cover" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-cover">cover</a> were specified,
			whichever would result in a smaller <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①④">concrete object size</a>.</p>
     <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Both <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-none" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-none③">none</a> and <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-cover" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-cover①">cover</a> respect the content’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-aspect-ratio" id="ref-for-natural-aspect-ratio①">natural aspect ratio</a>,
			so the concept of "smaller" is well-defined.</p>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="object-fit" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-object-fit-scale-down">scale-down</dfn> 
    <dd> Equivalent to <span class="css">contain scale-down</span>. 
   </dl>
   <details class="wpt-tests-block" dir="ltr" lang="en" open>
    <summary>Tests</summary>
    <ul class="wpt-tests-list">
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/inheritance.html" title="css/css-images/inheritance.html">inheritance.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/inheritance.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/inheritance.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001c.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001c.html">object-fit-contain-png-001c.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001c.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001c.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001e.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001e.html">object-fit-contain-png-001e.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001e.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001e.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001i.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001i.html">object-fit-contain-png-001i.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001i.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-contain-png-001i.html"><small>(source)</small></a>

     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005o.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005o.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-005o.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005o.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005o.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005p.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005p.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-005p.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005p.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-005p.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006e.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006e.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-006e.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006e.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006e.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006i.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006i.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-006i.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006i.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006i.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006o.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006o.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-006o.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006o.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006o.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006p.html" title="css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006p.html">object-fit-scale-down-svg-006p.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006p.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/object-fit-scale-down-svg-006p.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-computed.html" title="css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-computed.html">object-fit-computed.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-computed.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-computed.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-invalid.html" title="css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-invalid.html">object-fit-invalid.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-invalid.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-invalid.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
     <li class="wpt-test"><a class="wpt-name" href="https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-valid.html" title="css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-valid.html">object-fit-valid.html</a> <a class="wpt-live" href="http://wpt.live/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-valid.html"><small>(live test)</small></a> <a class="wpt-source" href="https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/css/css-images/parsing/object-fit-valid.html"><small>(source)</small></a>
    </ul>
   </details>
   <p>If the content does not completely fill the replaced element’s content box,
	the unfilled space shows the replaced element’s background.
	Since replaced elements always clip their contents to the content box,
	the content will never overflow.
	See the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#propdef-object-position" id="ref-for-propdef-object-position">object-position</a> property for positioning the object with respect to the content box.</p>
   <figure>
     <img alt height="116" src="images/img_scale.png" style="border: thin solid black;" width="488"> 
    <figcaption> An example showing how four of the values of <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-object-fit" id="ref-for-propdef-object-fit②">object-fit</a> cause the replaced element (blue figure)
			to be scaled to fit its height/width box (shown with a green background),
			using the initial value for <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#propdef-object-position" id="ref-for-propdef-object-position①">object-position</a>.
			In this case, <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-scale-down" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-scale-down②">scale-down</a> and <span class="css">scale-down contain</span> would look identical to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-contain" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-contain②">contain</a>,
			and <span class="css">scale-down cover</span> would look identical to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-object-fit-none" id="ref-for-valdef-object-fit-none④">none</a>. </figcaption>
   </figure>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-object-fit" id="ref-for-propdef-object-fit③">object-fit</a> property has similar semantics to
	the <code class="highlight">fit</code> attribute in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-smil10" title="Synchronized Multimedia Integration Language (SMIL) 1.0 Specification">[SMIL10]</a> and the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type">&lt;meetOrSlice></a> parameter
	on the <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/coords.html#PreserveAspectRatioAttribute"><code class="highlight">preserveAspectRatio</code> attribute</a> in <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-svg11" title="Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) 1.1 (Second Edition)">[SVG11]</a>.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> Per the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#object-size-negotiation" id="ref-for-object-size-negotiation①">object size negotiation</a> algorithm,
	the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#concrete-object-size" id="ref-for-concrete-object-size①⑤">concrete object size</a> (or, in this case, the size of the content)
	does not directly scale the object itself -
	it is merely passed to the object as information about the size of the visible canvas.
	How to then draw into that size is up to the image format.
	In particular, raster images always scale to the given size,
	while SVG uses the given size as the size of the "SVG Viewport"
	(a term defined by SVG)
	and then uses the values of several attributes on the root <code class="highlight">&lt;svg></code> element to determine how to draw itself.</p>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="6" id="image-processing"><span class="secno">6. </span><span class="content">Image Processing</span><a class="self-link" href="#image-processing"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>



</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="6.1" id="the-image-resolution"><span class="secno">6.1. </span><span class="content">Overriding Image Resolutions: the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-image-resolution" id="ref-for-propdef-image-resolution">image-resolution</a> property</span><a class="self-link" href="#the-image-resolution"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="image-resolution">image resolution</dfn> is defined as
	the number of image pixels per unit length,
	e.g., pixels per inch.
	Some image formats can record information about the resolution of images.
	This information can be helpful when determining the actual size of the image in the formatting process.
	However, the information can also be wrong,
	in which case it should be ignored.
	By default, CSS assumes a resolution of one image pixel per CSS <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#px" id="ref-for-px①">px</a> unit;
	however, the <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-image-resolution" id="ref-for-propdef-image-resolution①">image-resolution</a> property allows using some other resolution.</p>
   <table class="def propdef" data-link-for-hint="image-resolution">
    <tbody>
     <tr>
      <th>Name:
      <td><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="property" data-export id="propdef-image-resolution">image-resolution</dfn>
     <tr class="value">
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values/#value-defs">Value:</a>
      <td class="prod">[ from-image <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-any" id="ref-for-comb-any⑦">||</a> <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value③">&lt;resolution></a> ] <a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#comb-all" id="ref-for-comb-all②">&amp;&amp;</a> snap<a data-link-type="grammar" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#mult-opt" id="ref-for-mult-opt①⑨">?</a> 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#initial-values">Initial:</a>
      <td>1dppx 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#applies-to">Applies to:</a>
      <td><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-pseudo/#generated-content" title="Includes ::before and ::after pseudo-elements.">all elements</a> 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#inherited-property">Inherited:</a>
      <td>yes 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values/#percentages">Percentages:</a>
      <td>n/a 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-cascade/#computed">Computed value:</a>
      <td>specified keyword(s) and/or <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value④">&lt;resolution></a> (possibly adjusted for <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-image-resolution-snap" id="ref-for-valdef-image-resolution-snap">snap</a>, see below) 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/cssom/#serializing-css-values">Canonical order:</a>
      <td>per grammar 
     <tr>
      <th><a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/web-animations/#animation-type">Animation type:</a>
      <td>discrete 
   </table>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-b0a6fceb"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-b0a6fceb"></a> The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①②">image-set()</a> notation can alter the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#--natural-resolution" id="ref-for---natural-resolution④">natural resolution</a> of an image,
	which ideally would be automatically honored without having to set this property.
	How should we best address this?
	Change the initial value to <span class="css">auto</span>, meaning "1dppx, unless CSS says otherwise"?
	Say that image-resolution has no effect on images whose resolution was set by something else in CSS?
	Or somehow wordsmithing <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①③">image-set()</span> in some way such that it always produces <span class="css">1dppx</span> images somehow?</p>
   <p>The <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-image-resolution" id="ref-for-propdef-image-resolution②">image-resolution</a> property specifies the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#preferred-resolution" id="ref-for-preferred-resolution">preferred resolution</a> of all raster images used in or on the element.
	It affects both content images
	(e.g. replaced elements and generated content)
	and decorative images
	(such as <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-backgrounds-3/#propdef-background-image" id="ref-for-propdef-background-image②">background-image</a>).
	The <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="preferred-resolution">preferred resolution</dfn> of an image is used to determine the image’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#natural-dimensions" id="ref-for-natural-dimensions⑨">natural dimensions</a>.
	Values have the following meanings:</p>
   <dl>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="image-resolution" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-image-resolution-resolution"><a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value⑤">&lt;resolution></a></dfn> 
    <dd> Specifies the <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#preferred-resolution" id="ref-for-preferred-resolution①">preferred resolution</a> explicitly.
			A "dot" in this case corresponds to a single image pixel. 
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="image-resolution" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-image-resolution-from-image">from-image</dfn> 
    <dd>
      The image’s <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#preferred-resolution" id="ref-for-preferred-resolution②">preferred resolution</a> is taken as that specified by the image format
			(the <dfn class="dfn-paneled" data-dfn-for="/" data-dfn-type="dfn" data-export id="--natural-resolution">natural resolution</dfn>).
			If the image does not specify its own resolution,
			the explicitly specified resolution is used (if given),
			else it defaults to <span class="css">1dppx</span>. 
     <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> <a href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#url-metadata"><cite>CSS Images 3</cite> § 2.1.2 Image Metadata</a> imposes some restrictions on what metadata can be used.</p>
    <dt><dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-for="image-resolution" data-dfn-type="value" data-export id="valdef-image-resolution-snap">snap</dfn> 
    <dd> If the "snap" keyword is provided,
			the computed <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#resolution-value" id="ref-for-resolution-value⑥">&lt;resolution></a> (if any)
			is the specified resolution rounded to the nearest value
			that would map one image pixel to an integer number of device pixels.
			If the resolution is taken from the image,
			then the used <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#--natural-resolution" id="ref-for---natural-resolution⑤">natural resolution</a> is the image’s native resolution similarly adjusted. 
   </dl>
   <p>As vector formats such as SVG do not have a <a data-link-type="dfn" href="#--natural-resolution" id="ref-for---natural-resolution⑥">natural resolution</a>,
	this property has no effect on vector images.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-image-resolution">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-image-resolution"></a> Printers tend to have substantially higher resolution than computer monitors;
		due to this, an image that looks fine on the screen may look pixelated when printed out.
		The <a class="property css" data-link-type="property" href="#propdef-image-resolution" id="ref-for-propdef-image-resolution③">image-resolution</a> property can be used to embed a high-resolution image into the document
		and maintain an appropriate size,
		ensuring attractive display both on screen and on paper: 
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img.high-res <c- p>{</c->
  <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>300</c-><c- k>dpi</c-><c- p>;</c->
<c- p>}</c->
</pre>
    <p>With this set, an image meant to be 5 inches wide at 300dpi
		will actually display as 5in wide;
		without this set,
		the image would display as approximately 15.6in wide
		since the image is 15000 image pixels across,
		and by default CSS displays 96 image pixels per inch.</p>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-resolution-from-image">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-resolution-from-image"></a> Some image formats can encode the image resolution into the image data.
		This rule specifies that the UA should use the image resolution found in the image itself,
		falling back to 1 image pixel per CSS <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#px" id="ref-for-px②">px</a> unit. 
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> from-image <c- p>}</c-></pre>
    <p>These rules both specify that the UA should use the image resolution found in the image itself,
		but if the image has no resolution,
		the resolution is set to <span class="css">300dpi</span> instead of the default <span class="css">1dppx</span>.</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> from-image <c- m>300</c-><c- k>dpi</c-> <c- p>}</c->
img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>300</c-><c- k>dpi</c-> from-image <c- p>}</c->
</pre>
   </div>
   <div class="example" id="ex-resolution-300">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-resolution-300"></a> Using this rule, the image resolution is set to 300dpi.
		(The resolution in the image, if any, is ignored.) 
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>300</c-><c- k>dpi</c-> <c- p>}</c-></pre>
    <p>This rule, on the other hand,
		if used when the screen’s resolution is 96dpi,
		would instead render the image at 288dpi
		(so that 3 image pixels map to 1 device pixel):</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> <c- m>300</c-><c- k>dpi</c-> snap<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c-></pre>
    <p>The <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#valdef-image-resolution-snap" id="ref-for-valdef-image-resolution-snap①">snap</a> keyword can also be used when the resolution is taken from the image:</p>
<pre class="lang-css highlight">img <c- p>{</c-> <c- k>image-resolution</c-><c- p>:</c-> snap from-image<c- p>;</c-> <c- p>}</c-></pre>
    <p>An image declaring itself as 300dpi will,
		in the situation above,
		display at 288dpi
		(3 image pixels per device pixel)
		whereas an image declaring 72dpi will render at 96dpi
		(1 image pixel per device pixel).</p>
   </div>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="7" id="interpolation"><span class="secno">7. </span><span class="content">Interpolation</span><a class="self-link" href="#interpolation"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>This section describes how to interpolate between new value types defined in this specification,
	for use with modules such as CSS Transitions and CSS Animations.</p>
   <p>If an algorithm below simply states that two values should be "interpolated" or "transitioned" without further details,
	then the value should be interpolated as described by the Transitions spec.
	Otherwise, the algorithm may reference a variable <var>t</var> in its detailed description of the interpolation.
	This is a number which starts at 0% and goes to 100%,
	and is set to a value that represents the progress through the transition,
	based on the duration of the transition,
	the elapsed time,
	and the timing function in use.
	For example, with a linear timing function and a 1s duration,
	after .3s <var>t</var> is equal to 30%.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.1" id="interpolating-images"><span class="secno">7.1. </span><span class="content">Interpolating <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-image" id="ref-for-typedef-image②⓪">&lt;image></a></span><a class="self-link" href="#interpolating-images"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>All images can be interpolated,
	though some special types of images
	(like some gradients)
	have their own special interpolation rules.
	In general terms,
	images are interpolated by scaling them to the size of the <var>start image</var> and cross-fading the two while they transition to the size of the <var>end image</var>.</p>
   <p>In specific terms,
	at each point in the interpolation
	the image is equal to <code class="highlight"><c- nf>cross-fade</c-><c- p>(</c-> <c- p>(</c-><c- m>100</c-><c- k>%</c-> - <var>t</var><c- p>)</c-> <var>start image</var><c- p>,</c-> <var>end image</var><c- p>)</c-></code>.</p>
   <p class="issue" id="issue-d366087c"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-d366087c"></a> Special-case interpolating to/from no image,
	like "background-image: url(foo);" to "background-image: none;".</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.2" id="interpolating-image-combinations"><span class="secno">7.2. </span><span class="content">Interpolating cross-fade()</span><a class="self-link" href="#interpolating-image-combinations"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>The three components of <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①④">cross-fade()</a> are interpolated independently.
	Note this may result in nested <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①⑤">cross-fade()</span> notations.</p>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.3" id="interpolating-gradients"><span class="secno">7.3. </span><span class="content">Interpolating <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-gradient" id="ref-for-typedef-gradient②">&lt;gradient></a></span><a class="self-link" href="#interpolating-gradients"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p class="issue" id="issue-f1783900"><a class="self-link" href="#issue-f1783900"></a> This section needs review and improvement.
	In particular, I believe the handling of linear-gradient() is incomplete -
	I think we want to specifically interpolate the "length" of the gradient line
	(the distance between 0% and 100%)
	between the starting and ending positions explicitly,
	so it doesn’t grow and then shrink over a single animation.</p>
   <p>Gradient images can be interpolated directly in CSS transitions and animations,
	smoothly animating from one gradient to another.
	There are only a few restrictions on what gradients are allowed to be interpolated:</p>
   <ol>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Both the starting and ending gradient must be expressed with the same function.
(For example, you can transition from a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient⑥">linear-gradient()</a> to a <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient⑦">linear-gradient()</span>,
but not from a <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-linear-gradient⑧">linear-gradient()</span> to a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-4/#funcdef-radial-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-radial-gradient④">radial-gradient()</a> or a <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient" id="ref-for-funcdef-repeating-linear-gradient④">repeating-linear-gradient()</a>.)</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Both the starting and ending gradient must have the same number of <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stop" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stop">&lt;color-stop></a>s.
For this purpose, all repeating gradients are considered to have infinite color stops,
and thus all repeating gradients match in this respect.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Neither gradient uses a combination of <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value④">&lt;length></a> and <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value⑤">&lt;percentage></a> color stops.</p>
   </ol>
   <p>If the two gradients satisfy all of those constraints,
	they must be interpolated as described below.
	If they fail the third one only,
	they must be abruptly transitioned at 50%
	(unless otherwise specified by a future specification).
	If they fail either of the first two constraints,
	they must be interpolated using <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①⑥">cross-fade()</a> as for generic images.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The abrupt transition at 50% is so that content will not rely on cross-fading,
	and smarter interpolation rules can be added for this case in the future.</p>
   <ol>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Convert both the start and end gradients to their explicit forms:</p>
     <dl>
      <dt data-md>For linear gradients:
      <dd data-md>
       <ul>
        <li data-md>
         <p>If the direction is specified as an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value⑥">&lt;angle></a>,
it is already in its explicit form.</p>
        <li data-md>
         <p>Otherwise,
change its direction to an <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#angle-value" id="ref-for-angle-value⑦">&lt;angle></a> in [<span class="css">0deg</span>,<span class="css">360deg</span>)
that would produce an equivalent rendering.</p>
         <p>If both the start and end gradients had their direction specified with keywords,
and the absolute difference between the angles their directions mapped to is greater than 180deg,
add 360deg to the direction of the gradient with the smaller angle. <span class="note">This ensures that a transition from, for example,
"to left" (270deg) to "to top" (0deg)
rotates the gradient a quarter-turn clockwise,
as expected,
rather than rotating three-quarters of a turn counter-clockwise.</span></p>
       </ul>
      <dt data-md>For radial gradients:
      <dd data-md>
       <ul>
        <li data-md>
         <p>If the size is specified as two <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value⑤">&lt;length></a>s or <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value⑥">&lt;percentage></a>s,
it is already in its explicit form.</p>
        <li data-md>
         <p>Otherwise, the size must be changed to a pair of <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#length-value" id="ref-for-length-value⑥">&lt;length></a>s
that would produce an equivalent ending-shape.
If the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#typedef-radial-shape" id="ref-for-typedef-radial-shape②">&lt;radial-shape></a> was specified as <a class="css" data-link-type="value" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#valdef-radial-shape-circle" id="ref-for-valdef-radial-shape-circle">circle</a>,
change it to <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-images-3/#valdef-radial-shape-ellipse" id="ref-for-valdef-radial-shape-ellipse">ellipse</a>.</p>
       </ul>
     </dl>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Interpolate each component and color-stop of the gradients independently.
For linear gradients,
the only component is the angle.
For radial gradients,
the components are the horizontal and vertical position of the center
and the horizontal and vertical axis lengths.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>To interpolate a color-stop,
first match each color-stop in the start gradient
to the corresponding color-stop at the same index in the end gradient.
For repeating gradients,
the first specified color-stop in the start and end gradients
are considered to be at the same index,
and all other color-stops following and preceding are indexed appropriately,
repeating and shifting each gradient’s list of color-stops as needed.
Then, for each pair of color-stops,
interpolate the position and color independently.</p>
   </ol>

</details>
<h3 class="heading settled" data-level="7.4" id="interpolating-stripes"><span class="secno">7.4. </span><span class="content">Interpolating <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes⑤">stripes()</a></span><a class="self-link" href="#interpolating-stripes"></a></h3>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="3">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>Similar to gradients,
	two <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-stripes" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes⑥">stripes()</a> can be interpolated,
	allowing for smooth animations from one image to another.
	There are only a few restrictions on what <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-stripes⑦">stripes()</span> are allowed to be interpolated:</p>
   <ol>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Both the starting and ending image must have the same number of <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="#typedef-color-stripe" id="ref-for-typedef-color-stripe③">&lt;color-stripe></a>s.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Each pair of interpolated thicknesses must be of the same type,
i.e. both must either be of type <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#typedef-length-percentage" id="ref-for-typedef-length-percentage⑤">&lt;length-percentage></a>, or <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-grid-2/#typedef-flex" id="ref-for-typedef-flex①①">&lt;flex></a>.</p>
   </ol>
   <p>If the two images satisfy both constraints,
	they must be interpolated as described below.
	If they fail the second one only,
	they must be abruptly transitioned at 50%
	(unless otherwise specified by a future specification).
	If they fail the first constraint,
	they must be interpolated using <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①⑦">cross-fade()</a> as for generic images.</p>
   <p class="note" role="note"><span class="marker">Note:</span> The abrupt transition at 50% is so that content will not rely on cross-fading,
	and smarter interpolation rules can be added for this case in the future.</p>
   <ol>
    <li data-md>
     <p>Interpolate each component and stripe of the images independently.</p>
    <li data-md>
     <p>To interpolate a stripe,
first match each stripe in the start image
to the corresponding stripe at the same index in the end image.
Then, for each pair of stripes,
interpolate the thickness
and color independently.</p>
   </ol>

</details>
<h2 class="heading settled" data-level="8" id="serialization"><span class="secno">8. </span><span class="content">Serialization</span><a class="self-link" href="#serialization"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>This section describes the serialization of all new properties and value types introduced in this specification,
	for the purpose of interfacing with the CSS Object Model <a data-link-type="biblio" href="#biblio-cssom" title="CSS Object Model (CSSOM)">[CSSOM]</a>.</p>
   <p>To serialize any function defined in this module,
	serialize it per its individual grammar,
	in the order its grammar is written in,
	omitting components when possible without changing the meaning,
	joining space-separated tokens with a single space,
	and following each serialized comma with a single space.</p>
   <p>For <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-cross-fade" id="ref-for-funcdef-cross-fade①⑧">cross-fade()</a>,
	always serialize the <a class="production css" data-link-type="type" href="https://www.w3.org/TR/css-values-4/#percentage-value" id="ref-for-percentage-value⑦">&lt;percentage></a>.</p>
   <div class="example" id="ex-serialize-gradient">
    <a class="self-link" href="#ex-serialize-gradient"></a> For example, a gradient specified as: 
<pre class="highlight"><c- nf>Linear-Gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-> to bottom<c- p>,</c-> red <c- m>0</c-><c- k>%</c-><c- p>,</c->yellow<c- p>,</c->black <c- m>100</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c-></pre>
    <p>must serialize as:</p>
<pre class="highlight"><c- nf>linear-gradient</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- nf>rgb</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>255</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>),</c-> <c- nf>rgb</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>255</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>255</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>),</c-> <c- nf>rgb</c-><c- p>(</c-><c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>,</c-> <c- m>0</c-><c- p>)</c-> <c- m>100</c-><c- k>px</c-><c- p>)</c-></pre>
   </div>

</details>
<h2 class="no-num heading settled" id="deprecated"><span class="content"> Appendix A: Deprecated Features and Aliases</span><a class="self-link" href="#deprecated"></a></h2>
<details class="valor-spec" data-level="2">
  <summary>Show spec text</summary>

<p>Implementations must accept <dfn class="dfn-paneled css" data-dfn-type="function" data-export id="funcdef--webkit-image-set">-webkit-image-set()</dfn> as a parse-time alias of <a class="css" data-link-type="maybe" href="#funcdef-image-set" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①④">image-set()</a>.
	(It’s a valid value, with identical arguments to <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①⑤">image-set()</span>,
	and is turned into <span class="css" id="ref-for-funcdef-image-set①⑥">image-set()</span> during parsing.)</p>

</details>
